title: Advanced Spanish Through Literature & Film
description: HISP 0650 aims to study literature and film from Latin America and Spain through critical reading and analytical writing. This section is thematic: the majority of its contents revolve around the representation of the self. We will read first person literature, autobiographies, diaries, and myriad other genres, focusing on how they inform our notions of memory, authorship and identity. The course will serve as an introduction to the literatures and cultures of the Spanish-speaking world, covering a range of periods and genres (the story, the novel, poetry, film, and non-fiction). Beyond offering a historical and contextualized panorama of cultural production from the Spanish-speaking world, HISP 0650 will also help you develop new strategies for reading, writing, and thinking about literature and film, preparing you for more advanced literature and culture courses at the 1000 level.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HISP 0600 or minimum score of 5 in 'AP Spanish Language'.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Spanish Through Literature & Film
description: HISP 0650 aims to study literature and film from Latin America and Spain through critical reading and analytical writing. This section is thematic: the majority of its contents revolve around the representation of the self. We will read first person literature, autobiographies, diaries, and myriad other genres, focusing on how they inform our notions of memory, authorship and identity. The course will serve as an introduction to the literatures and cultures of the Spanish-speaking world, covering a range of periods and genres (the story, the novel, poetry, film, and non-fiction). Beyond offering a historical and contextualized panorama of cultural production from the Spanish-speaking world, HISP 0650 will also help you develop new strategies for reading, writing, and thinking about literature and film, preparing you for more advanced literature and culture courses at the 1000 level.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HISP 0600 or minimum score of 5 in 'AP Spanish Language'.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intensive Survey of Spanish Literature
description: HISP740, Intensive Survey of Spanish Literature, provides students with an overview of Spain's major authors and literary movements from the Middle Ages to the present day. This course offers a varied introduction to Spanish literature in its historical and cultural contexts through the reading and analysis of poetry, essay, theater, and narrative fiction. There are two principal objectives for this class: a) to expose students to Spain's cultural production and familiarize them with both canonical as well as non-canonical texts; b) to teach students to critically engage with and analyze literature in its historical and culture context. Reading chronologically, students will be able to appreciate the development of the Spanish literary tradition as they ask critical questions about identity, race, the nation, and cultural formation. Conducted in Spanish.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HISP 0600, 0650, minimum score of 5 in 'AP Spanish Literature' or minimum score of 750 in 'SATSubj-Spanish'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Latin American Diaspora in the US
description: This engaged course is designed to bridge academic learning about Latin American diasporic history and culture and volunteer work in agencies serving Latinx communities in Providence. Readings, films, and guest presentations examine the ways in which the Latinx community has imagined itself and has been imagined by others. Spanish language learning occurs in the classroom and the community, where students have the opportunity to enrich and test course content. Conducted in Spanish, Spanglish welcome. Prerequisite: HISP 0600 or placement: SAT II scores of over 750, 5 in AP Literature or 651 and over in the Brown Placement Exam.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HISP 0600, 0650, minimum score of 5 in 'AP Spanish Literature', minimum score of 750 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 760 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 770 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 780 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 790 in 'SATSubj-Spanish' or minimum score of 800 in 'SATSubj-Spanish'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Health, Illness and Medicine in Spanish and Spanish American Literature and Film
description: In this class we will read/see, discuss and write about texts and films that deal with health, illness, death and medicine in Spanish and Spanish American contexts. Our approach will be informed by principals of Narrative Medicine that demonstrate how attending to, representing and affiliating oneself with other human beings by studying literature and the arts can transform relationships between patients and healthcare professionals. We will be honing our reading and analytical skills as we confront the subjective dimensions of illness and medicine from humanistic and cross-cultural perspectives. This course is conducted in Spanish.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HISP 0600, 0650, minimum score of 5 in 'AP Spanish Literature', minimum score of 760 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 770 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 780 in 'SATSubj-Spanish', minimum score of 790 in 'SATSubj-Spanish' or minimum score of 800 in 'SATSubj-Spanish'.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: A Nation in its Labyrinth: An Introduction to Colombia
description: Tobacco, Rubber, Bananas, Coffee, Coca, Orchids… The image of Colombia has traveled the world under the guise of tropical products linked to speed, pleasure, violence and exoticism. But what lies behind the deceiving, magical spell of these traveling products? This course will travel back from the product to the place where these plants were tended to and flourished. The works of renowned artists such as García Márquez and lesser-known masters like Marvel Moreno or Débora Arango will allow us to read against the grain the history of a country crisscrossed by the diversity of its people and the beauty of its environments. Even though the histories of violence and social conflict will traverse this course, so will the warm sounds of cumbia, the voices of its poets and the green joy of its landscapes.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Medieval Masterpieces
description: Examines three medieval Spanish masterpieces: Cantar de Mio Cid, Libro de buen amor, and Celestina. Other works are read to explore lines of continuity and discontinuity in these three works and their respective genres.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Emergence of the Vernacular: Prestige and Critique (Spanish & Italian)
description: Using pertinent sources drawn primarily from Latin, Spanish, Italian, and their early variants, this class will study the emergence and development of the vernacular from its beginnings through the Early Modern period. We will consider theorizations of vernacularity alongside some of its most pressing debates as they circulated throughout Spain, Italy, and the Americas, in particular. To this end, we will examine historical sources that exemplify the wide reach of the sociopolitical, linguistic, and identitary anxieties and violences surrounding linguistic development, while concentrating our attentions on literary sources (prose, drama, poetry) and didactic manuals and epistles that directly comment upon the status of language(s), vilifying, defending, redefining, or reaffirming them. Students should be proficient in either Spanish or Italian, and have advanced reading abilities in the other.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Exploring and Extracting in Colonial Latin American Literatures
description: This graduate seminar provides a panorama of Latin American literatures during the period covered by the Colonial preliminary exam list. Historiographically, this period has been termed Europe's age of exploration. From the Americas, however, it could be better characterized as the age of extraction. We will probe the writings of key authors and texts from Colonial Latin America on the tension between exploring (associated with the deeply human capacity for curiosity and wonder) and extracting (the result of the also very human impulse to possess and accumulate). In our readings, we will see how at times the two are indistinguishable (a slippage that is evident in the Portuguese "exploraçao" meaning "exploitation"); at others, we will glimpse at the authors' desire to replenish landscapes, restitute rights and reimagine worldviews beyond the regimes brought forth by the adjective "Colonial". Conducted in Spanish.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Ocean in Global History
description: This course examines how the ocean and its denizens have influenced and been shaped by diverse social, material, political, and cultural factors across different spaces and chronologies. We will consider how historical actors across global history have approached the ocean and its creatures as sources of sustenance and power, cosmology and knowledge, conveyance and death. We will weigh, too, how adopting an oceanic perspective can open new ways of understanding the past, present, and future of our planet and its inhabitants. Topics considered include contemporary and historic Indigenous seafaring traditions and maritime subjectivities across Moana/Pacific and other oceanic basins; Atlantic seaborne empires, piracy, human trafficking in the age of sail; the establishment of oceanography as a scholarly discipline; the evolution of maritime transportation infrastructure under global capitalism; the political ecology of a warming ocean in the era of climate crisis.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.

title: Curators, Hoarders, and Looters: The Long and Curious History of Collecting
description: What does it mean to collect? What drives human cultures to amass, hoard, steal, select, separate and display objects? This undergraduate lecture course – at the intersection of anthropology, geography, history, and museum studies – examines forms and practices of collecting from antiquity to the present. We will explore museums, archives, libraries, and other less formal institutions from around the globe, probing in the process the disciplinary boundaries by which scholars have sought to understand the implications of collections in different times and distant territories. We will unpack libraries, visit early modern cabinets of curiosities, and gain insights into Indigenous collections: from Polynesia to Mashantucket. And we will address the fraught yet fascinating relationship between the collection, the catalogue, and the archive – and the gathering, registering, and organizing that constitute them.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Southeast Asian History
description: From Melaka to Manila, and from sultanates to megacities, this new course introduces students to the plural past of Southeast Asia. In doing so, it analyzes how the region came to be (as a field of study in the mid-twentieth century), while surveying, too, the ways in which histories of polity, port, empire, and revolution have shaped not only the world in Southeast Asia—but also Southeast Asia in the world.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Modern Latin America
description: This course is an introduction to the history of modern Latin America. Through lectures, discussions, shared readings, we will explore major themes in the past two hundred years of Latin American history, from the early nineteenth-century independence movements to the recent "Left Turn" in Latin American politics. Some of the topics we will examine include the racial politics of state-formation; the fraught history of U.S.-Latin American relations; the cultural politics of nationalism; how modernity was defined in relation to gender and sexuality; and the emergence of authoritarian regimes and revolutionary mobilizations, and the role of religion in shaping these processes.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The American Civil War
description: This course, covering the period roughly from 1820-1865 and focusing mostly on 1860-1865, examines the origins of the Civil War, the war itself, and preliminary efforts at reconstruction during wartime. The class meetings and readings will focus on the transformation wrought by the war, investigating in particular certain issues relevant to current affairs: 1) enslavement, emancipation, and struggles for equality; 2) sectionalism, secession, and insurrection; 3) the role of law in the prosecution and resolution of war; and 4) the role of the Civil War in American popular culture and politics. There are no prerequisites--the course is accessible to students at all levels--but some knowledge of U.S. history might be useful.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Latinx History
description: This course provides a comprehensive historical examination of Latinx people in the United States. Students will explore major questions, theory, and research methods pertinent to the historical narratives of Mexican Americans, Puerto Ricans, Dominican Americans, Cuban Americans, and Central Americans. Major topics of study include immigration, ethnic identity formation, social and political activism, labor, and articulations of race, gender, and culture in urban and rural settings. This course ultimately demonstrates how the Latinx experience is vital to our understanding of the social, economic, and cultural history of the United States.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History of Artificial Intelligence
description: The course will trace the origins and trajectory of ideas about artificial intelligence, starting with the "active intellect" of Aristotle, early analog computers and automata, Ada Lovelace's "calculus of the nervous system," through the "general intellect" and "machine capital" of Karl Marx, Karel Čapek's "Universal Robots," the "Turing test," "cyberpositivity" and Donna Haraway's "Cyborg Manifesto," and concepts like "swarm intelligence," "hive mind," "singularity," and the "master algorithm." Sources will encompass a range of disciplinary approaches (philosophy, sociology, computer science, etc.), formats (text, film, graphic novel), and genres including Japanese anime and Afrofuturism.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Welfare States and a History of Modern Life
description: History of the American welfare state, from its origins in nineteenth-century industrial capitalism to contemporary debates about health care, in comparative perspective. Why did welfare states appear and what form did the U.S. version take? Considerations of social inequality, labor relations, race, gender, family policy, the social wage, and the relationship between markets and the state are all considered. Some comparison with European models.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Unnatural Disasters: Rethinking Histories of Catastrophe in the Americas
description: Since Hurricane Katrina, the history of natural disasters and the new interdisciplinary field of critical disaster studies have surfaced. Both fields of agree that natural disasters are windows onto the societies they strike and are processes emerging from historical human and nonhuman causes. Natural disasters, they agree, are unnatural. Studying a range of environmental processes from melting glaciers in the Andes to radioactive pollution west of Rockies, this course adopts a hemispheric scope to connect geographical, temporal, and thematic fields of history. We will think together about the agency of American environments and the hazards that haunt them. We draw on diverse methods to examine the roles that race, power, indigeneity, disability, gender, and science play in the history of (un)natural disasters. These methods will help us analyze primary sources while also encouraging curiosity for overlooked American communities and environments.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Indigenous Education
description: This course examines contemporary Indigenous issues through the lens of education. Why were colonial schools established? What was the legacy of colonial schooling? How has reconciliation been sought? How have Indigenous communities responded? Students will examine current issues and how they relate to historical processes such as Indigenous epistemologies; the origins, development, decline, and legacy of the federal residential, boarding, and day school system; the meaning of apologies; and the importance of language revitalization. Additionally, students will study how Indigenous activists, storytellers, and artists have used colonial mediums to combat colonialism and resist epistemicide: the eradication of Indigenous knowledge. Students will use discussion periods to analyze and reflect on their own lives and how their gender, ethnicity, and privilege relates to, contributes to, or challenges, Indigenous issues. Topics/themes include colonization, treaties, justice, truth and reconciliation, Indigenous leadership, and Indigenous resistance.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Knowledge and Power: Material Culture History of Tibetan Buddhism during the Qing Dynasty 17-19th c
description: The mid-seventeenth century ushered in a series of momentous political changes in China and Tibet. The Dalai Lama-led Ganden Phodrang state emerged in Lhasa with the ambitious ruler and his coterie displaying their power through new art and infrastructure. Further east, the Manchus, despite being a minority in Confucian China, rose to become the Qing emperors in Beijing. As they expanded the empire's territories to include the Inner Asian regions of Mongolia and Tibet, they projected a complex model of Buddhist kingship to gain legitimacy among the new subjects. How are these historical developments reflected in the material and print culture of this period (17th-19th centuries)? Each week, we will cover one theme of Buddhist material culture. Topics include book publishing and written technology; monastic architecture and replication of infrastructure; creation of statues, paintings and ritual objects among others.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Postwar Japan
description: This course is for students interested in exploring Japan's remarkable cultural, political and social transformations from the closing days of the Second World War, through its emergence as an apparent exemplar of democratization's potential and capitalism's benefits, and on to the contemporary era. Lectures, readings and films will explore the legacies of the war and the Occupation, the so-called "economic miracle" (and its effects on the environment), the protest movements of the 1960s and beyond, and Japan's complicated relationships with its neighbors, with the U.S., and with its own recent history. Open to all students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Viking Age
description: For two centuries, Viking marauders struck terror into hearts of European Christians. Feared as raiders, Norsemen were also traders and explorers who maintained a network of connections stretching from North America to Baghdad and who developed a complex civilization that was deeply concerned with power and its abuses, the role of law in society, and the corrosive power of violence. This class examines the tensions and transformations within Norse society between AD 750 and 1100 and how people living in the Viking world sought to devise solutions to the challenges that confronted them as their world expanded and changed. P
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Global British Empire, 1600-The Present
description: This course charts the long history and continuing legacies of the British Empire, an entity that has transformed every single continent over the last four centuries and is widely associated with the makings of the modern world. We examine how and why a powerful and expansive British Empire emerged and sustained itself. Equally, we zoom in on the regular contestation and even outright rebellion that this transcontinental polity inspired. This course is an opportunity to think connectively and comparatively about historical experiences in America, India, the Caribbean, and Africa among multiple other British imperial spaces. We will track the making and unmaking of the British Empire by studying the evolution of global trade, labor regimes including slavery, the consumption of commodities such as sugar, as well as new ideas about governance, race, and identity.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Paris: Sacred and Profane, Imagined and Real
description: Paris has been called the capital of modernity, the capital of the nineteenth century, and the capital of the black Atlantic. This course explores how Paris grew from a small settlement into a vast city with an enormous global impact. Covering the settlement of the Celtic Parisii in the mid-third century BCE through the present, the course investigates the dynamic relationship between urban space, public activism, racism, and colonialism. It also considers who has been excluded from the city's complex mythology and how these myths impacted experiences of the "other" (including people of color, low-income people, Jewish people, and women).
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History of the Andes
description: Before the Spanish invaded in the 1530s, western South America was the scene of the largest state the New World had ever known, Tawantinsuyu, the Inca empire. During almost 300 years of colonial rule, the Andean provinces were shared by the "Republic of Spaniards" and the "Republic of Indians" - two separate societies, one dominating and exploiting the other. Today the region remains in many ways colonial, as Quechua- and Aymara-speaking villagers face a Spanish-speaking state, as well as an ever-more-integrated world market, the pressures of neoliberal reform from international banks, and the melting of the Andean glaciers.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The American Revolution
description: This course will explore the period of the American Revolution from the 1760s through the turn of the nineteenth century. Taking a broad view of the conflict and its consequences, we will situate the American colonies in their North American and Atlantic context, examine the material and ideological concerns that prompted the Revolutionary War, and trace the consequences of the conflict for the nation that followed. Students will be invited to look beyond the Founders to the experiences of women, slaves, Native Americans, common soldiers, and Loyalists.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Cities and Inequality Since 1920: The United States
description: This lecture course takes up the relationship between cities and social and economic inequality—especially racial, but also other forms of social disadvantage along lines of class, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, and geography. Its focus is the urban history of American cities, suburbs, and towns and how urban development since the advent of the motor-car suburb in the 1920s shaped American social life. Students will learn about and explore topics such as zoning, racial redlining and other forms of segregation, real estate markets, the home building industry, urban public policy and law, urban leisure, transportation, and many others. At the center of the course is the question of how people live in dense connectivity and community and what the history of the modern American city can tell us about the nature and durability of social inequality.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Intellectual History of Black Women
description: This course will introduce students to the intellectual productions and theoretical traditions of African American women. Focused on the canonical texts of African American women, this class gestures toward diaspora as well. Moving chronologically from the history of slavery to the present will require that we simultaneously confront the question of what counts as "intellectual" history. Thus even as we will read the written words of black feminists across time, we will also call into question what Barbara Christian calls "the race for theory," turning also to resistance practices, material culture, and bodily performance as sites of black feminist theorization.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: From Medieval Bedlam to Prozac Nation: Intimate Histories of Psychiatry and Self
description: Humankind has long sought out keepers of its secrets and interpreters of its dreams: seers, priests, and, finally, psychiatrists. This lecture course will introduce students to the history of psychiatry in Europe, the United States, and beyond, from its pre-modern antecedents through the present day. Our focus will be on the long age of asylum psychiatry, but we will also consider the medical and social histories that intersect with, but are not contained by, asylum psychiatry: the rise of modern diagnostic systems, psychoanalysis, sexuality and stigma, race, eugenics, and pharmaceutical presents and futures.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Legal History: The Case of the Middle East
description: This seminar is devoted to exploring questions of law and legal history in the Middle East. Together we shall navigate a range of imperial, colonial, and national legal systems in the region via select case studies from early modern to contemporary times. Major themes include not only Islamicate legal traditions and jurisdictions, but the intersections, tensions, and synergy between Islamic law and Roman, Persianate, and European imperial legacies; fellow Abrahamic faiths and the interplay between religion and secularism; and the evolving role of international law including human rights and humanitarian law. From early schools of Islamic jurisprudence to Ottoman, Egyptian, and Iranian constitutions, and the role of lawyers and judiciaries from decolonization to the Arab Spring uprisings, our goal is to explore the depth, diversity, and transformation of legal cultures and institutions across different epochs of Middle East history.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Thinking Historically: A History of History Writing
description: Philosopher George Santayana famously warned that "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it." Ten years later, industrialist Henry Ford perhaps even more famously dismissed that notion: "History is more or less bunk." What we mean by history and how we construct and use it are essential questions in all societies. Thinking Historically explores how we view and employ the past. The course examines major ways of interpreting the past through a survey of historians and methods and studies how history is produced, used, and misused, by professionals as well as by the public.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: On the Move: Problems and Histories of Tourism and Mobilities
description: This course examines histories of modern recreational tourism and the politics of mobility more generally. Tourism is a fascinating point of departure through which we can examine how histories of empire, consumerism, gender, and the environment all converge upon practices many (but certainly not all) of us take for granted. The premise of this seminar is based on two basic questions: through tourism, how do we change a place and how does that place change us? How does human mobility produce a new set of economic, social, and political relations? The answers will vary across time and space, but through engagement with scholarship and various primary sources we can come to better understand how the pleasure modern-day travelers derive from temporarily being someplace else is ultimately something deeply embedded into the structures and historical processes of the modern world itself.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Indigeneity and Assimilation in Southern Africa: The Khoe-San
description: South Africa is infamous for apartheid, the starkest form of settler colonialism. Yet 20th-century segregation reversed centuries of assimilationist policies against South Africa's First Peoples: the Khoe-San. From the mid-17th century, this distinctive cultural group endured environmental and epidemiological shocks, conquest, and genocide. Their descendants only survived within a Dutch-speaking underclass. This seminar traces their survivance: from early encounters and violent subjugation to claims-making against 19th century British liberalism, ending with recent assertions of indigeneity among "Coloured" descendants in decolonizing South Africa. Khoe-San history—trauma, adaptation, and endurance—forms a crucial chapter in African history and comparative colonial history. P
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: North African History: 1800 to Present
description: This course focuses on the francophone Maghrib (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia) and offers an introduction to major themes in the history of Africa and the Arab world in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Students will gain the tools to analyze and historicize the dynamic history of this region. We will examine a range of topics, including the transformations of pre-colonial social, economic and cultural patterns, conquest and resistance, comparative histories of colonialism, nationalism, decolonization and revolution, the consolidation of postcolonial states, regional cooperation, the rise of Islamism and civil conflicts, and the Arab Spring.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Making Revolutionary Cuba, 1959-Present
description: In January 1959, the forces of rebel leader Fidel Castro entered Havana and forever altered the destiny of their nation and world. This seminar will consider the six decades that followed the rise of a new revolutionary order, as well as its global repercussions. We will examine how political hegemony was achieved as well as the silences and exclusions on which it rested, with particular attention to ideology, race, sexuality, and culture.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: America and the Middle East: Histories of Connection and Exchange
description: This seminar explores the history of connection and exchange between the diverse peoples and societies of two constructed regions: the Middle East and North America. Proceeding chronologically, we begin with the global context of Columbus's fateful voyage in 1492, before turning to colonial Spanish, Portuguese, and English-British intersections with the Ottoman Empire and Morocco. While including Latin American, Caribbean, and Canadian case studies, the bulk of our course explores US ties to the "Mideast/MENA" region during the 19 th -21 st centuries. Yet, this isn't a conventional course in diplomatic history. Rather, we'll read closely for underlying socioeconomic, cultural, and intellectual processes—trade, migration, education, and evolving conceptions of race, religion, and citizenship—themes often overlooked by foreign relations, watershed events, or conflict. Our goal: to recognize how US-Middle East ties are far more complex, rich, and deep-rooted than is generally assumed.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Israel-Palestine: Lands and Peoples I
description: The Holocaust largely destroyed the centuries-long Jewish civilization in Europe. For Zionism, originating in late nineteenth-century antisemitism and East-Central European ethno-territorial nationalism, the "final solution" proved the need for a Jewish-majority state in Palestine. Yet the majority of the population in Eretz Israel was Palestinian. The creation of Israel in 1948 was the outcome of a bitter war with the local Arab population and the surrounding states, in the course of which most of the Palestinians were expelled or fled, facilitating the establishment of a Jewish-majority state. The seminar will discuss the fraught question of the two traumatic events of the Holocaust and the Nakba (the expulsion of 1948), and propose that we can both better understand these events, and begin the long path to reconciliation, by applying the tools of empathetic first-person history.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Early American and Atlantic Money
description: The history of finance has become a crucial site for studying governance and statecraft, for recovering the organizing logic of capitalism, and for recognizing the structures of power in any given society. Topics include the recurring debates over metallic and paper currencies, the emergence of a national banking systems, and the technologies of coinage, assaying, and counterfeiting. Particular focus on the relationship among finance, colonization, and slavery, as well as the many speculative monetary systems that circled around the Atlantic world from the fifteenth century through the nineteenth century.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Modern South Asia and the Image Archive
description: This seminar will look at how historians, art historians and artists have used an array of visual materials in the archive to make arguments about the past. We will read texts on the history of photography, on popular ephemera, from film studies, as well as interrogate the work of artists who draw on archives. How do we "read" images, interpret them, and how have they impacted our understanding of the past?
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Environmental Pressures of South Asia
description: South Asia is one of the most densely populated geographical regions of the world. The traditional environmentalist view of separating/protecting 'nature' from human settlements often leads to conflicts of resources/land use here. This course studies the evolution of environmental governance in the diverse ecologies of South Asia across four substantive and methodological parts. Part I involves readings on environmental and agrarian systems in the Mughal Empire from the precolonial period (1526-1757) in South Asia. Part II involves readings on forestry laws from the British colonial period (1757-1947) in South Asia. Part III involves reviewing a series of books and films on environmental history in Asia. Part IV involves researching case studies focusing on local environment cultures from the postcolonial period (1947 to present) in South Asia. The course requires writing a final research paper based on a case study.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Modern Environmental Movements from Conservation to the Rights of Nature
description: What are the politics of creating and maintaining a livable Earth after industrialization? How has the environment figured in movements for equality and justice? This senior seminar examines environmental issues and responses under capitalism in North America and socialism in Russia and Eastern Europe. The course covers conservation and preservation; Indigenous anticolonial movements; responses to chemical and plastic pollution; anti-nuclear protest; environmental justice; climate change and anti-fossil fuel movements; and new forms of environmental organizing including the Rights of Nature movement and degrowth. Focused on the 19th and 20th centuries, the class will situate movements in ecological, political, and economic context, assess outcomes, and examine the relationships between economic form and politics. Using primary and secondary sources in a range of media, seminars will include short lectures, discussions, and student-led case studies that build toward a substantive final research project.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Planning the Family
description: This course explores 20th-century efforts to address population growth and family planning in a variety of global contexts, ranging from macro-level initiatives to individual practices. For some women, state leaders, and international experts, contraception meant sexual liberation, increased autonomy, and the reduction of economic hardship. But for others, the same biomedical technologies were associated with colonial control and efforts to reduce "undesirable" people. How is it possible for contraception to hold such expansive and contradictory meanings? In order to assess this central question, students will engage with critical theories of gender, race, class, nationalism, and decolonization.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Climates of Inequality: The Plantation-to-Petrochemical Complex
description: What is the relationship between land, labor, and global capitalist modernity? How does studying environmental injustice help resituate America's colonial past and its imperial present? This interdisciplinary course introduces students to one of the most pressing environmental justice struggles in the nation today: Cancer Alley, USA. Together, we will explore the entwined histories of slavery, settler colonialism, and racial capitalism in Louisiana and the broader Gulf South, connecting colonial history to ongoing forms of state violence. Readings draw heavily from Environmental History, Native American and Indigenous Studies (NAIS), and Black Studies to address themes of ecological devastation and embodied violence, while also highlighting practices of resistance and resurgence from historical uprisings to contemporary cultural revitalization efforts. Students will learn to critically analyze how racialized systems of power and privilege structure inequality while envisioning alternative, more just futures.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Worlds on the Move:  Migration and Exchange Across Europe and the Mediterranean, 1492–1700
description: How did people travel across the Mediterranean in the early modern period? What documents and economic resources enabled their mobility? How did cities respond to migration, and what did it mean to cross borders in a world of empires, republics, and religious frontiers? This course explores the mechanisms and experiences of movement, examining how migration shaped the cultural, social, and political development of early modern societies. Drawing on the instructor's expertise, the course places special emphasis on female mobility and the influence of gender relations on migratory experiences. Students will engage with various primary sources, such as archival documents, maps, iconographic materials, and literary texts, which will provide them with essential tools and methods for practicing history and deepen their understanding of how historians work.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History of Healing, Medicine, Technology, and Global Health in Africa
description: History of Healing, Medicine, Technology, and Global Health in Africa will examine the political, social, and cultural dimensions of health and healing across the African continent. Through historical case studies and contemporary debates, students will explore how indigenous knowledge, medical technologies, and public health interventions have shaped, and have been shaped by, Africans, colonialism, nationalist movements, and global health agendas. Students will be required to participate in a workshop and engage with primary and secondary sources to analyze the intersections of medicine, science, and technology and global health. Students will participate in seminar discussions and expert-led sessions, develop a research project that critically examines a historical or contemporary issue in African health and healing, and produce written reflections, reports, and oral presentations that connect historical insights to present-day challenges. The course emphasizes interdisciplinary thinking, historical analysis, and persuasive communication skills.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History Honors Workshop for Prospective Thesis Writers
description: Prospective honors students are encouraged to enroll in HIST 1992 during semesters 5 or 6. HIST 1992 offers a consideration of historical methodology and techniques of writing and research with the goal of preparing to write a senior thesis in history. The course helps students refine research skills, define a project, and prepare a thesis prospectus, which is required for admission to honors. Students who complete honors may count HIST 1992 as a concentration requirement. Limited to juniors who qualify for the honors program.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the History (AB) program.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History Honors Workshop for Thesis Writers, Part I
description: All students admitted to the History Honors Program must enroll in HIST 1993 for two semesters of thesis research and writing. They may enroll in the course during semesters 6 and 7, or 7 and 8. Course work entails researching, organizing, writing a history honors thesis. Presentation of work and critique of peers' work required. Limited to seniors and juniors who have been admitted to History Honors Program. HIST 1993 is a mandatory S/NC course. See History Concentration Honors Requirements.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the History (AB) program.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History Honors Workshop for Thesis Writers, Part II
description: This is the second half of a year-long course, upon completion the grade will revert to HIST 1993. Prerequisite: HIST 1993.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HIST 1993 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Roots of History
description: "The Roots of History" encourages critical thinking about some of the different ways in which historians approach thinking and writing about the past. In particular, we will explore some of the major theoretical stances that have influenced the discipline of history. Our focus throughout will be the interplay between theory and practice. By examining how historians have grappled with questions posed by influential thinkers (often working within other fields of knowledge), we will chart the trajectory of the discipline and assess its working methods. Required for all first-year PhD students in History.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Practice of History
description: This graduate seminar is about the professional skills, tools, and careers of historians—from hallmark best practices to new directions. We will engage different kinds of careers historians are pursuing today, the practical skills and resources necessary to meet them, and how historians are deploying those skills in multiple professional arenas, both in and beyond the academy. We shall also discuss some of the prevalent (although often unwritten) social and cultural norms of academia and university life to prepare you to navigate your training, career, and various institutional contexts that accompany and follow completion of a Ph.D. in History
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Ancient History (PHD), History (AM) or History (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Prospectus Development Seminar
description: This collaborative seminar focuses on identifying and contextualizing a dissertation topic; choosing a dissertation committee and a support network; designing and executing plans for research and writing; and articulating a thesis project as a prospectus, grant proposal, and other oral and written forms. This is a required course for and open only to third-year students in the History Ph.D. program.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Rethinking the Civil Rights Movement
description: This graduate course encourages a rethinking of the complex components, arguments and activities that have characterized what we have come to know as the Civil Rights Movement, concentrating primarily on African American agency, actions and politics, through careful reading of recent scholarship in the field. While knowledge of U.S. history is preferred, this course asks larger thematic questions about protest movements (the role of the state, relationships with and between oppressed groups and organizations, and periodization), that will interest non-Americanists also. Some of the topics covered include: gender, organizing and strategies, the local, global ramifications and interactions, organizational structures and politics, and the recent concept of the Long Civil Rights Movement. M
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Latin American Historiography
description: This course examines the development of historical writings on Latin America produced in the United States from the late nineteenth century until the present. We will focus on themes, such as race, gender, labor, subaltern studies, dependency theory, postcolonial analysis, and post-modernism, to understand the diverse approaches to Latin American history. M
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Orientalism
description: Europe's fascination with "the Orient" generated a major tradition of intellectual, literary, and artistic production, beginning in the medieval era and persisting to the present day. This seminar explores the social and intellectual history of Orientalism, considering the ways that it has intersected with the study of power, race, sexuality, religion, and language. Readings to include Edward Said's seminal work on this subject alongside several critiques, correctives, and debates that have emerged in recent years.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Perspectives on Jewish History
description: Jewish history has a complex dynamic. The development of Jewish society is fed not only by Jewish tradition but also by developments in non-Jewish society. Equally, the place of Jews in the non-Jewish world is determined not only by the attitudes of non-Jews but also by the economic, social, and political agency wielded by Jews themselves. This graduate seminar will, in a broad chronological framework, examine the complicated interplay of forces which shaped both the Jewish experience in the non-Jewish world and the non-Jewish world's treatment of its Jewish minority. Among the topics to be discussed: the places of Jews in premodern Christian and Muslim societies; Jewish early modernity; the historical trajectory of Jew-hate; changing Jewish responses to non-Jewish culture; Jewish power, powerlessness, and political development; the modern Jewish experience before, during, and after the Holocaust.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History Dissertation Writing Workshop
description: This seminar is for History PhD students in residence at Brown who are post-exams and are at any stage of writing their dissertations. It is intended to support dissertators by providing a structured community for setting and sharing goals, writing, and discussing chapters-in-progress. It meets every other week and is a half credit S/NC course.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Environment, Violence, Repair
description: Recent conversations in environmental justice foreground harm and repair, as the scope of environmental questions expands to include exposure, toxicity, war, and infrastructures. This seminar positions violence and repair as entry-points to an ethnographic understanding of environmental harm, disturbance, and change through an interdisciplinary body of work that includes environmental history and film. The course connects recent ethnographic accounts of exposure, extraction, and pollution to critiques of violence, imperialism, and statecraft, and asks about the possibilities and limitations of repair, refusal, and survival. Reading critical theory on violence next to environmental degradation opens up space to think and learn about how colonial and state projects terra/aqua-form the environment and lifeways and calls us to think critically about environmental struggles from the perspective of resistance, repair, and non-western and non-secular responses to disaster, disruption, and change.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Cogut Institute for the Humanities Research Seminar
description: This yearlong seminar involves reading and discussing in-progress research by the annual fellows of the Cogut Institute for the Humanities, an interdisciplinary group of faculty, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates engaged in extended research on a major project or honors thesis. Students read a wide range of works-in-progress, prepare questions and participate in seminar discussions, serve as first questioners for specific sessions assigned to them in advance, and present their own work twice during the year. Students are required to complete both semesters (HMAN 1000A in the fall and HMAN 1000B in the spring) to receive credit. Admission to the course requires that students have received the Cogut Institute Undergraduate Fellowship for the year in which they enroll. More information about the fellowship and application process may be found at https://humanities.brown.edu/apply/undergraduate-fellowship.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: We the People
description: How do individual people come together to make a People? We will read key ancient texts including Aristotle, Livy, and Cicero, enlightenment thinkers like Rousseau and Hobbes, and modern theorists from Arendt and Schmitt to Chakrabarty and Mouffe to see how the "we" of We the People has been used both to include and exclude. We will also consider practices of political action both ancient and modern. Can a People create itself by a vote, a manifesto, or a riot? What is the relationship between the People and populism? The course is explicitly grounded in the ancient world; as well as analyzing how ancient concepts have echoed through the centuries, we will also look to the distant past for difference, asking how we might propose alternative genealogies of the People.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Settler Colonial Cities: Indigenous Histories, Presents, and Futures
description: The course examines the Indigenous histories, presents, and futures of settler colonial cities. Founded on Indigenous lands expropriated for town building, modern cities in settler colonial societies were and are complicit in processes displacing Indigenous people and appropriating their cultures, objects, and ancestors. We will draw on anthropology, archaeology, archival history, geography, heritage preservation, public art, and urban studies to explore colonialist tactics of spatial removal and symbolic and documentary violence aimed at erasure. Most importantly, we will look at how Indigenous people have challenged claims of their absence in urbanizing landscapes through their oral histories, writing, and material culture, and by their presence and diverse experiences in cities in the United States, Canada, Australia, and beyond.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Bottom Ecologies: Blackness, Queerness, and the Environment
description: How have Black queer communities — and minoritarian communities more broadly — transformed environments of shame and disposability into sources of erotic power, pleasure, and collective survival? Building on Toni Morrison's "Sula" and theories from Black feminisms, queer-of-color critique, and Black ecological thought, this course views the "bottom" as Black queer ecological thought. We will trace how Black queer communities generate counter-knowledge, reshape racialized and sexual subjectivities, and challenge conventional environmental discourse by queering ecological analysis. Ultimately, this course examines the "bottom" as both a sexual position and an ecological site historically raced, and marked as disposable, dirty, abject. Readings from Morrison, Jennifer Nash, Audre Lorde, Darieck Scott, Juana María Rodríguez, Kathryn Bond Stockton, and Leo Bersani will guide our exploration of how landscapes of racial abjection and erotic desire converge, offering new critical tools for environmental humanities.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
description: Digital humanities uses digital methodologies and formats to answer humanities research questions, produce and share knowledge, and teach. It encompasses critical studies of digital environments, innovative modes of researching and advancing arguments (including methodologies for constituting archives, analyzing texts and images, and visualizing data), new forms of scholarly and general publications, and digital pedagogy. The digital changes the way we research, understand, and share information in the humanities. This course will introduce students to a range of methodologies and critical lenses. Students will learn to collect resources formatted for machine-actionable research, analyze qualitative and quantitative datasets, and visualize and present their findings. They will consider the ethics of digital work and publication. Each student will plan a digital humanities project. This course is open to all graduate students and fulfills a requirement for the doctoral certificate in digital humanities.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Digital Humanities Capstone Seminar
description: Participants in the Digital Humanities Capstone Seminar will learn how to design and build their own digital humanities project and/or participate as a key member on an already established digital humanities project with a faculty leader through hands-on, step by step instruction. Students will grapple with key methodologies and theoretical frameworks (including critical, Black, Indigenous, and Latinx digital humanities) and consider how to situate their own work within these ideas. Seminar participants will participate in the Digital Humanities Salon, where they will also present their project. Where desired and advisable, the capstone project may build toward dissertation work. Admission in the course is conditional on enrollment in the doctoral certificate in digital humanities, and partial or full completion of the digital tools and methods requirement.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: From Big Data to Lilliputians: Considerations of Scale Across the Disciplines
description: We live in an era of big problems and small details. It is a time of globalization and atomization, of big data and nanotechnology—nothing is too minute to escape surveillance, regulation, or sale, and scalability is often used as a measure of success. Scale is the stuff of awe and the sublime and the feeling of utter insignificance. Can one person's behavior change the way an entire system works ("personalized medicine," or climate change)? When does a change in scale mean a change in kind? Is morality/ethics a question of scale? Should we think big, or is the devil in the details? We will discuss the theme of "Scale" from a variety of historical and other perspectives with texts from philosophy, literature, history of science, theology, psychology, sociology, and political theory, as well as film and poetry.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Approaches to Environmental Humanities Research
description: This collaborative, interdisciplinary seminar engages modes of inquiry in environmental humanities research and accounts for a range of theories and methods that encompass qualitative, historical, decolonial, and community-engaged scholarships, among others. The seminar focuses in particular on human and nonhuman relations and their impacts on environmental change, drawing on concepts and practices such as survivance, duration, weathering, extraction, and geological time. In addition to scholarly and theoretical texts, we will explore films, novels, creative nonfiction, and performances. Assignments help students engage and refine approaches to environmental scholarly inquiry and practice in a time of intensifying planetary and local crisis.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Project Development Workshop
description: In this capstone course, students completing the Doctoral Certificate in Collaborative Humanities pursue individual or collaborative projects, such as a dissertation chapter, an article on method/theory, or a stand-alone essay related to the larger field. The workshop provides a collaborative and supportive space in which students from different disciplines can share their work and receive and give feedback that will broaden and sharpen the framing of their projects. At the end of the semester, participants present in a Collaborative Public Workshop. Admission to the seminar requires a formal application process and the completion of two HMAN 2400 seminars.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Order of Evils: Phenomenological, Moral, and Political Investigations
description: A critical reading of "The Order of Evils: Toward an Ontology of Morals" (2000), a "poststructuralist" moral treatise that combines phenomenological and structural analysis and is attuned to the historicity of knowledge and moral matters. The book understands evil as discrete harm, which becomes a moral matter only once it is judged as gratuitous, and an object of critique only once it is grasped in its regularity. The seminar, oriented toward revising the book, reexamines the reasoning that supports these intuitions and their implications: a transformation of moral discourse; a new ontology of "moral things"; the primacy of others over the self; a downgrade of "liberty," "justice," and "rights"; and a critical interest in the historical conditions of political action. Seminar participants will also read works by thinkers who inspired the project, including Kant, Marx, Heidegger, Levinas, Lyotard, and Derrida.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Beginning Hindi or Urdu
description: Introduces conversation, reading, and writing of modern standard Hindi and the Devanagari script. Those who already know Devanagari but have rusty conversation skills may join the class second semester; obtain instructor's permission during the first semester. Those who prefer to learn Urdu and the Persian script should contact the instructor. Prerequisite: HNDI 0100.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: HNDI 0100.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
description: A continuation of HNDI 0100-0200. Introduces the variation of the Persian script used for Urdu. Prepares students to communicate in written and spoken language. Activities are conducted in Hindi/Urdu. Meets four hours weekly. Prerequisite: HNDI 0300.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: HNDI 0300.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu
description: Each student follows an independent reading list determined in consultation with the instructor. The readings may include folk tales, journalistic prose, 20th-century literature, classical Urdu poetry of the 17th to 19th centuries, or subjects in nonfiction. The class meets together three hours weekly for discussion. Each student also spends one hour weekly with the instructor. Prerequisite: HNDI 0400.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: HNDI 0400 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Costs of War
description: This interdisciplinary seminar explores a ground-level view of war and its human, economic, environmental, and social consequences. We primarily take up the example of the post-9/11 wars, focusing less on the causes of war, on battles, elite war strategies, or relations between states than on what war is like for those caught within it, what larger social and economic contexts make it more or less likely, what are its impacts for many differently situated peoples, and how myths about violence, and even the category of war itself, often obscures fuller understanding.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.

title: Reimagining Human Security
description: The concept of human security– in both theory and practice– has significantly evolved over the past two decades, with the idea that people, and the protection of human life and dignity, should be the central focus of governmental and intergovernmental security policy and practice. Yet, despite many advances in the field, the world is more dangerous than ever, and vulnerable civilians are increasingly threatened by a multitude of challenges including war, climate change, pandemics, natural disasters, the erosion of humanitarian and human rights law, and rapid advances in world-changing technologies. How do global issues such as climate change, pandemics, artificial intelligence, and migration impact human security? In what ways do social, economic, environmental, and political factors intersect in the context of human security? What ethical considerations should be considered when reimagining approaches to human security?
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: National Security Decision Making
description: Why do world leaders sometimes choose the foreign policies that end disastrously? This undergraduate lecture examines theories of individual and group decision-making in the context of national security policy. It connects analytical perspectives from political science, social psychology, and organizational theory with a wide variety of historical cases featuring the United States, Soviet Union, China, India, Pakistan, Iraq, and Vietnam. What constitutes an "effective" decision-making process? What types of individuals, groups and institutions foster more effective processes? When are individuals or groups prone towards risky decisions? Do decision-making processes matter in "high-stakes" issues, such as war and peace? The last third of the course will examine these questions in the context of the 2018 US-China Trade War.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Foundations of Development
description: This course presents an interdisciplinary approach to the study of development. The course examines what constitutes development from a variety of different disciplinary perspectives, and the course examines how and in what context the term "development" itself has evolved over time. The goal of this course is to provide students an intellectual and conceptual grounding for study a variety of issues surrounding development, whether in the global North or South.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Foundations of Security
description: This course introduces students to contemporary international security topics with a special focus on problems associated with war and violent conflict in the 21st century. It mixes the theoretical, historical, analytical, and practical. Students learn theory on the causes of war, how wars are fought, civil-military relations, the costs and consequences of warfare, and more. They also learn about the organization of the U.S. and other national security establishments. Using these tools, we will apply social science methods and critical thinking to security "hot spots" and wars around the world. There will be an emphasis on analyzing the unfolding war in Ukraine, as well as the prospects for U.S.-China rivalry and/or military conflict in the future, including within a Taiwan scenario. Aside from readings, lectures and discussions, students will benefit from a variety of films, simulations, walking excursions, and debates.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Nonprofit Organizations
description: Contemporary nonprofits and their role in community building and shaping public policy are central to this course. Topics include how strong coalitions impact housing, welfare and children's policy, organizing empowered communities, the influential and engaged donor and building the value of nonprofits. Case studies will be featured and new nonprofit models will be conceptualized to strategically address critical human need. Enrollment limited to 20 juniors, seniors, and graduate students concentrating in Public Policy. This course satisfies the American Institutions requirement.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Research Design and Methods
description: This course provides an introduction to research design in the social sciences. The goals of the course are two-fold: to instruct students to critically analyze scholarly articles in terms of research design and to guide students in designing an original research project. The methods presented in the course include qualitative methods (e.g., interviews, focus groups, participant observation, and process tracing) and quantitative methods (e.g., surveys, observational studies, and experiments). The course is designed as preparation for a senior thesis or original research project. All assignments in the course revolve around the development of an original research project. The research itself will not be conducted as part of the course. There are no prerequisites for the course and a background in statistics is not required.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Energy, Climate and Society
description: Energy shapes society, from the daily lives of local communities to patterns of global inequality. In this course, we explore the social dimensions of energy production and consumption. We start by examining fossil fuels and their wide-ranging effects on communities and the environment, then shift to the ongoing energy transitions and the social forces that help or hinder the large-scale adoption of renewables. Throughout the course, we will ask who benefits and who bears the costs of energy production and transition, and focus on understanding the equity implications of these changes and the prospects for a sustainable society. Students will develop policy analysis skills by identifying current energy challenges, assessing their social impacts, and proposing evidence-based solutions.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Contemporary Approaches to International Security Research
description: This seminar surveys a variety of contemporary scholarship—not classic texts—related to international security. We will critically engage recent arguments that draw upon a range of theoretical and empirical approaches to explain the determinants and consequences of war and peace. The course begins with a relatively cursory introduction to political science theory, design, and empirics. Each subsequent week investigates a particular area of scholarly attention, introducing students to a handful of recent contributions. Class time will be used to provide short lectures that provide background on each issue area, as well as for broader group discussion. The course will expose students to the 'cutting edge' in international security research, and provide the analytical tools to evaluate and contribute themselves.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Mexican Migration and US Immigration Policy
description: This course traces the history of Mexican migration and its relationship to US immigration policy. It uses Mexican migration as a case study—a lens through which to engage key topics in the study of migration, such as the construction of borders, the historical continency of legality, the social determinants of migratory departure, and the impacts of migration on sending and receiving communities. This course shifts between history and the present moment to develop a layered understanding of migration and to contemplate how immigration policy has functioned in the past and may function in the future. It centers the experiences of migrants and their families as they navigate leaving home and building lives in a country simultaneously reliant on and hostile to their presence, offering insight into a complicated and shifting reality affecting millions on both sides of the border.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Public Opinion, Social Media, and Politics
description: This course explores the role of public opinion, introducing the dynamics of citizens' social and political attitudes, especially focusing on the intersection of social media and politics. This course will introduce a multitude of topics on the political consequences of social media use including political participation, polarization, emotional well-being, and campaign advertisements. Theoretically, we will dive into understanding the classical theories in public opinion and extend to applications of how and why social media influence political behavior and attitudes. Empirically, the course will focus on practical, hands-on experience with analyzing real-world data, primarily using pre-existing datasets, surveys, and tools for data analysis, to gain insight into social science research.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Crime and Punishment in Global Perspective
description: Why do we believe crimes deserve punishment? In this course, we'll explore how societies around the world criminalize people, activities, and substances to justify the punishment of transgressions. Each week, we'll examine a case from a different country, such as abortion in Mexico, evidence fabrication in India, organized crime in the United States, mass incarceration in Brazil, or police violence in France. We'll watch international films, listen to podcasts, and read across disciplines like anthropology, law, sociology, and political science to understand how criminalization affects people's lives and question the philosophical reasons behind punishment. You will leave the course with an analytical toolkit to rethink justice systems and develop innovative alternatives.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: What Makes Policies Work?
description: What happens after laws and policies are enacted? What makes policy work in practice? What does it take – in terms of policy designs, resources, organizations, politics, expertise, and more – to turn formal rules into lived realities? How might this this differ across populations, over time, and over different geographic spaces? This course will take up these puzzles by examining multiple aspects of policymaking -- mobilization, policy designs, policy enactment, implementation, outcomes – across policy domains including k-12 education, health policy, social policy, elections policy, and more. Class members will have opportunities to examine the development and experience of policy in other domains through their independent research projects. This course is designed as a Junior seminar for the IAPA concentration and is open to IAPA and Political Science concentrators.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) or Political Science (AB) programs.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Diplomacy and Development: Related but Different Missions
description: This course will explore two international relations missions—diplomacy and development cooperation-- that complement one another but differ in substance and nature. Diplomacy, comprised of statecraft, policy formulation, representation, reporting and negotiation, will be treated in opening segments. The diplomatic mission is about influencing other sovereign states to bridge national differences in an effort to promote interests and avoid conflict. The course will explore these aspects using simulations, including a mock negotiation, a congressional hearing, and other pedagogical approaches.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Diplomacy and Development: Related but Different Missions
description: This course will explore two international relations missions—diplomacy and development cooperation-- that complement one another but differ in substance and nature. Diplomacy, comprised of statecraft, policy formulation, representation, reporting and negotiation, will be treated in opening segments. The diplomatic mission is about influencing other sovereign states to bridge national differences in an effort to promote interests and avoid conflict.
