registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.

title: Inequality and Social Mobility in America
description: Income and wealth inequality in America are at their highest levels in a century. Historically, one reason Americans have been thought to tolerate inequality is that we tend to believe that our society is a mobile one, where people can easily move from one social class to another. But in recent years, inequality and stagnant social mobility have been associated with increasing social and political distrust and unrest. In this junior seminar, we will examine the economic and political, and ideological factors that have contributed to this historical moment, learn about how Americans experience living in an unequal society, and consider the future of equality and social mobility in the United States. How should our society be shaped, and what are our obligations as members of that society?
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05 or 06.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Urban Ethnography and Public Policy
description: Ethnography is a social science method in which the researcher participates in and closely observes the lives of others — getting, as Erving Goffman once put it, "close to them while they are responding to what life does to them." Since the early twentieth century, urban ethnographers have used this approach to understand how city life "works," revealing how people produce, interpret, and respond to the social forces that shape everyday urban experience. This course uses ethnographic inquiry to examine how urban policy intersects with individual lives. How are large-scale programs and institutions created, implemented, and experienced through daily encounters between residents, service providers, and public institutions?
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Corporate Law and Public Policy
description: This course will give students an introduction to business organizations – the law that governs corporations and partnerships, how they raise money in the financial markets, and to explore the public policy issues that inform the regulation of business and finance. We will look at business organizations, law that governs how companies raise money, operation of the stock markets, insider trading, and the regulation of institutional investors including mutual funds, hedge funds and private equity funds. We will finish by taking up corporations as persons, their social obligations and the recent Supreme Court cases on corporations and the First Amendment. Overrides granted based on random drawing for 11 seniors and 8 juniors; to be eligible you must turn in the first week's assignment and attend the first class. Put course in your cart to access the assignment via canvas.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Human Rights and AI: Impacts, Risks, and Opportunities
description: Technology is not magic—it's power, coded and deployed. Artificial intelligence is becoming one of the most powerful forces shaping our future, determining who has access to opportunity, whose voices are heard, and how resources and rights are distributed. The Human Rights and AI seminar explores the complex, rapidly evolving landscape of AI and its profound impacts on human rights at the intersection of technology, public policy, and international law. Will AI hollow out our civil and human rights through invisible, automated systems that surveil, sort, and silence? Can AI serve liberation and justice if shaped, designed, and deployed from a rights-respecting framework? We will critically analyze both the harms and opportunities that AI poses to fundamental rights, and if civil and human rights laws and frameworks are relevant to responsible AI governance.

title: International Security Seminar:  Dynamics of Great Power Rivalry
description: This course examines the most dangerous phenomenon in contemporary international relation today: great power rivalry. We will investigate the main drivers of great power rivalry, its manifestations across varying geographic and functional domains, as well possible methods for mitigating rivalry. While discussions will touch on middle powers and alternative great powers, the focus will be on U.S. relations with both Russia and also China. Special attention is given to the various flashpoints in these relationships, whether the on-going Ukraine War or the South China Sea and also Taiwan. Rivalry dynamics will be assessed at all the various levels of intensity, ranging from influence operations to hybrid conflicts to limited wars and even to nuclear operations. Special attention will be paid to the costs of war, as well as to ways to restrain rivalry, including dialogue, institutions, and arms control.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Politics of Regulation: Technology, Finance, and Climate Change
description: Technological innovations are a central force for economic development, but today we are facing some of their most severe and unintended consequences. Some observers argue that only market competition can enable the blossoming of human ingenuity, while others argue that state planning is essential for controlling the dangers inherent in new technologies. Rather than extol or deny the benefits that can come from technology, this course examines how governments in different historical circumstances have attempted to shape and regulate three of the most challenging risks facing advanced societies.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Iran and the Islamic Revolution
description: Shattering events of 1978-80 in Iran unfolded against the backdrop of the previous decades of Iranian history, knowing that history is essential to understanding the revolution. The revolution cannot be appreciated without studying the enormous effects it's had over the last 35 years. This course places the anti-Shah movement and the rise of religious power in the context of Iran's century of modern history. We conclude by focusing on today's Iran, the upheaval following the 2009 election, reformist president election in 2013, and prospects for reconciliation with the US. Enrollment limited to 20 juniors & seniors. Priority given to IR seniors.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Overcoming Threats to Human Security
description: This course provides students with a comprehensive introduction to exploring challenges and opportunities related to global challenges from both a human and national security perspective – with a special focus on putting people and communities, as opposed to national interests, at the center of attention. Students will gain a deep understanding of key issues including humanitarian crises caused by natural disasters, and the impacts of climate change, food and water security, urbanization, mass migration, and infectious disease/pandemics on vulnerable people around the world.

title: State and Nation Building in Communist and Post Communist Europe
description: This seminar investigates the politics of state-building and nation-building in communist and post-communist Eastern Europe since World War I. The course is designed as a Senior Seminar for the IAPA concentration, and its major requirement is the writing of a 25-to-30-page research paper on a subject of the student's choosing (Capstone Project). Ideally, students will come to the course with some idea of a problem or question that the want to spend the better part of the semester researching. The seminar, however, is open anybody with a demonstrated interest in the region and who is ready to read and seriously discuss texts drawn from a wide range of vocations –from literature and politics, to history, philosophy, economics, sociology, political science, and public policy.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Politics of Reproductive Justice
description: Catherine MacKinnon once said "feminism has no theory of the state." She could also have said "scholars of the state have no theory of feminism." Thankfully times have changed. In this class, we will aim to understand why we need to think about states and gender together. We will investigate this intersection by focusing on a pressing contemporary issue: reproductive rights. Throughout the course, we will think through several questions. Why do states govern reproductive decisions and what strategies do state officials use? Does state intervention in reproduction reflect assumptions about masculinity and femininity? Does state intervention exacerbate or attenuate gendered differences and inequalities? How do organized interest groups challenge or alter state policies? We will read literature from around the world, while paying special attention to the American case.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International and Public Affai (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Contemporary Digital Policy and Politics
description: This course will examine the politics and processes for making policies related to the internet and digital policy issues. We will examine current issues at the national level, including the White House and federal agencies, Congress, international institutions and industry on issues such as privacy and information security, and on debates like whether and how to regulate Big Tech. Topics covered include the creation of national policies at the White House, the regulatory process, legislation, standards, global implications and the politics of technological change.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Accelerated Elementary Italian
description: This is an intensive elementary language course designed for students with no previous knowledge of Italian. Knowledge of another Romance language, although not required, is recommended. The course develops basic communication skills in Italian and explores practices, products, and perspectives of Italian culture. Four meetings a week plus one conversation hour. This course is ideal for students interested in fast-tracking their language learning to meet Brown-in-Bologna requirements. Enrollment is limited to 15. Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Review of specific grammar problems. Reading of one novel and newspaper articles. Compositions and oral presentations. Three Italian films. Prerequisite: ITAL 0300, or placement by examination.

title: Advanced Italian II
description: A sixth semester course with intensive practice in speaking and writing. Short stories, poems, music, and movies will be used to discuss Italian Society from the Second World War through the present. We will explore some important themes--family, religion, gender, and politics. Class discussion, compositions, oral presentations, and a final paper. Prerequisite: ITAL 0500, placement by examination.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: ITAL 0500.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Opera: Italy Onstage and Backstage
description: Opera is one of Italy's most enduring contributions to the cultural world – but just exactly what is opera? How does it work and how has it been used throughout history to propose, support, and undermine ideas about topics as broad as nationalism, race, gender, and class? Through a focus on some of the most influential operas written in Italian, we will consider how this unique art form is both in dialogue with itself and the world around it. This course has no prerequisites and does not require prior knowledge of music nor opera.

title: Intensive Language and Culture Proseminar
description: The Intensive Language and Culture Proseminar is a mandatory course designed to prepare students enrolled in the Brown-in-Bologna program to function well within the academic and social context of Bologna and to deepen their knowledge of the political, cultural and social environment in which they will be living for the duration of the semester. The Proseminar includes three components: (1) Intensive Language and Culture; (2) Bologna hidden town; (3) a number of activities organized by the program throughout the semester and a number of individual mandatory activities. At the end of the Proseminar course students will attain an in-depth and experiential knowledge of the Italian society.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Cinema Neorealista Italiano
description: According to Pier Paolo Pasolini, Italian neorealism "represented the first act of critical consciousness, politically and ideologically, that Italy had of itself." This course aims to show some of the classic neorealist films made in Italy in the 1940s: from Luchino Visconti's Ossessione to Roberto Rossellini's Germania anno zero and Vittorio De Sica's Umberto D., neorealist cinema captures Italy's new gaze onto itself, onto its hardships and its hopes. This course will be taught in Italian.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ITAL 0600 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Great Authors and Works of Italian Renaissance: Ariosto’s Orlando furioso
description: This class will read the most successful narrative poem of the Early Modern European period, Ariosto's Orlando furioso ("The Madness of Orlando," 1516-32), a work so popular it increased European literacy and rivaled the Bible in editions published. It combined the genres of chivalric romance, the crusading epic, and the classic heroic epic, but features ladies-errant along with knights and shrewdly satirizes hypermasculine late feudalism (the philosopher Hegel claimed it had destroyed chivalry). It helped drive Cervantes' Don Quixote mad, fueled a fierce debate in relation to Tasso's crusade epic Jerusalem Delivered, and in England influenced Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, Lord Byron, and Virginia Woolf (Orlando, 1928). Depending on enrollment, we will read/discuss in Italian and/or English. Readers in English will field-test a new translation by Ariosto scholar Albert Ascoli to be published by Oxford University Press.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Cultures of Fascism
description: It has often been stated that fascism, as a totalitarian political system, could not produce a culture of its own but only propaganda or at best ideology. In this course we will explore this proposition by exploring some of fascism's products in texts, film, art and architecture through the lens of critics and theorists of fascism such as Arendt, Benjamin, Kracauer, Gramsci, Bataille, Primo Levi (among others). Our focus will be on the Italian and German examples.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Microhistory
description: Microhistory emerged in the 1970s in Italy, but was quickly embraced by scholars across the globe. Microhistory questioned totalizing explanations of historical change; rejected anachronism in all forms; and recovered the voices of individuals left out of traditional historical narratives. This course explores and critiques the method. Participants write an article in their area of interest, informed by microhistory. The course is taught in English.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Emergence of the Vernacular: Prestige and Critique (Spanish & Italian)
description: Using pertinent sources drawn primarily from Latin, Spanish, Italian, and their early variants, this class will study the emergence and development of the vernacular from its beginnings through the Early Modern period. We will consider theorizations of vernacularity alongside some of its most pressing debates as they circulated throughout Spain, Italy, and the Americas, in particular. To this end, we will examine historical sources that exemplify the wide reach of the sociopolitical, linguistic, and identitary anxieties and violences surrounding linguistic development, while concentrating our attentions on literary sources (prose, drama, poetry) and didactic manuals and epistles that directly comment upon the status of language(s), vilifying, defending, redefining, or reaffirming them. Students should be proficient in either Spanish or Italian, and have advanced reading abilities in the other.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Italian Studies Colloquium
description: The Italian Studies Colloquium is a forum for an exchange of ideas and work of the community of Italian scholars at Brown and invited outside scholars. Graduate students present their work in progress, and engage the work of faculty and visitors. They are expected to come prepared with informed questions on the topic presented. Presentations in both Italian and English. Instructor permission required.

title: Japanese Language Through Popular Culture
description: Japanese pop culture has been disseminated worldwide and it is one of the top reasons why people start studying Japanese today. This content-based language course examines various aspects of Japanese pop culture including but not limited to manga, anime, and video games. While students discuss topics related to Japanese pop culture, they will also learn grammar structures that enable them to write formal essays in Japanese. Through the materials of Japanese pop culture, students will also develop the skills needed to succeed in today's world, such as critical thinking, problem solving, creativity, digital literacy, and communication. Above all, this course will emphasize creativity and help students learn how to attract people.

title: American Jewish History from the Great Migration to the  Contemporary Resurgence of Antisemitism
description: In this course we will explore the forces that have shaped American Jewry and made it what it is today.  We will ask how the Jews who came to America as immigrants created a unique form of Jewish life that combined the political and social traditions of their old countries with the ethos and values they found here.  We will explore the place of American Jews in the Jewish world prior to World War II and how this affected the American Jewish public arena.  Our examination of the post-Holocaust years will focus on the creation of a new American Judaism, as well as the cultural, literary, and ideological accomplishments of American Jews.  Finally, we will discuss the development of antisemitism in the US from the 1920s to its contemporary resurgence.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Race, Sexuality, and the Jews
description: This seminar offers an interdisciplinary and intersectional examination of the historical and contemporary experiences of Jews from antiquity through the present. We will learn about social and cultural constructions of race, ethnicity, gender, and sexuality, focusing on Jews and other neighboring minority and majority communities; we will study how in different geographical and temporal spheres these communities have defined or blurred boundaries, shaping both distinctly visible and invisible characteristics; we will examine how perceptions of race and ethnicity have changed over time and across circumstances and how the traditional binary of men and women has been reinforced throughout but also how it has been challenged and altered in various contexts.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.

title: History of the Holocaust
description: Explores questions raised by the Holocaust regarding how such barbarism erupted in our so-called civilized and enlightened age. Attempts to analyze the meaning of the Holocaust from three vantage points: that of European, and more particularly, German history; that of Jewish history; and that of those states and religious institutions which shared responsibility. If unable to enroll because of closed registration please contact the professor and a wait list will be created.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Modern Jewish Peace Tradition: From Prophecy to Politics
description: This course explores the evolving meanings of shalom—peace—in modern Jewish thought and political life. Beginning with a brief overview of classical and rabbinic formulations of peace as divine harmony and moral obligation, we trace how contemporary Jewish thinkers, theologians, and activists have reinterpreted peace across contexts of modernity, nationalism, and conflict. From prophetic ethics and utopian socialism to the paradoxes of Zionism and the Israeli peace camp, students engage with theological, anthropological, and political debates that reveal peace as a deeply contested but enduring ideal. Readings combine theology, political theory, ethnography, and peace studies to illuminate how Jewish traditions of dialogue, justice, and moral restraint continue to shape the pursuit of coexistence in Israel/Palestine and beyond.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: History of the State of Israel: 1948 to the Present
description: This course surveys the history of Israel from its Proclamation of Independence in 1948 until today. Israel's history has unfolded under the shadow of its prolonged conflict with the Palestinians and its Arab neighbors. At the same time, an entirely new, vibrant and dynamic society and culture has developed there. This course aims to familiarize the student with the major outlines of Israel's development, and with different narratives and interpretations of that history. The reading materials and class discussions will examine not only the Arab-Israeli conflict, but also its influence on Israeli politics, society and culture.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Korean
description: Begins with an introduction to the Korean writing system (Hangul) and focuses on building communicative competence in modern Korean in the four language modalities (listening, speaking, reading, writing). Provides a foundation for later work in spoken and written Korean. Six classroom hours per week. Enrollment limited to 18. This is the second half of a year-long course. Students must have taken KREA 0100 to receive credit for this course. The final grade for this course will become the final grade for KREA 0100. If KREA 0100 was taken for credit then this course must be taken for credit; if taken as an audit, this course must also be taken as an audit. Exceptions to this policy must be approved by both the academic department and the Committee on Academic Standing.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Korean for Advanced Beginners
description: As a continuation of KREA0250 (Elementary Korean for Advanced Beginners), this course is also designed for heritage learners of Korean who have a foundational understanding of the language and wish to rapidly advance their proficiency. Focusing more on expanding vocabulary, refining grammar, and enhancing both oral and written communication, the course addresses the specific needs of heritage learners. Emphasis will be placed on conversational fluency, including smooth use of honorifics and cultural literacy. Students will explore authentic materials, engage in structured dialogues, and participate in discussions that connect language learning to their personal and cultural experiences.This course is ideal for learners who want to strengthen their ties to the Korean language and culture while accelerating their language learning journey.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: KREA 0250.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Korean
description: See Advanced Korean (KREA 0500) for course description. Prerequisite: KREA 0500 or equivalent or permission of instructor.

title: Business Korean
description: For students who are interested in Korean culture in general and business culture in particular, and in improving their Korean language skills in a business context. The course not only focuses on business and economy-related words and expressions, but also on developing learners' confidence in business writing, conversation and presentations in Korean. Enrollment limited to 15. Prerequisite: KREA 0600 or instructor's permission.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: KREA 0600.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Translating Korean: Fiction, Poetry & Film
description: This class explores the theory and practice of translation in the context of Korean cultural production. Each week we shall grapple with a particular issue in translation studies in dialogue with a Korean-language text. By the end of this course students should be able to locate the tools necessary to carry out translations from Korean to English, to demonstrate an understanding of translation as a craft with its own standards, responsibilities, and complexities, and to have completed a significant translation project themselves. Learners of the Korean language who have completed Korean 600 as well as native speakers of Korean are welcome.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Research and Methodologies in Latin American and Caribbean Studies
description: The course will offer students a collaborative learning environment where research ideas can be developed and discussed with fellow students and a range of LACA faculty. During the course, the instructor will facilitate the development of research ideas and expose students to research methods, tools, and resources specific to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean. Moreover, the instructor will train students to develop research and creative projects and enhance their ability to write and communicate their ideas, produce effective and generative research questions, and/or produce innovative creative projects in a robust and convincing manner. In addition, during the semester, students will benefit from interactive workshops led by the Brown Writing Center as well as visits to special collections at the John Hay Library, and guest speakers from different disciplines.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Protest and Dissidence in Iran
description: The anti-authoritarian Woman, Life, Freedom movement arose as a reaction to protests, incarceration and death in Iran in the fall of 2022. In this first-year seminar, you will learn about Iran, a country of 87 million people bordered by Iraq and Afghanistan. We will discuss historical events such as the 1979 Iranian Revolution and how they still affect Iran's relationship to the West. Through a broad selection of texts, film and art, we will explore topics that include corruption, authoritarianism, multiculturalism, race, social class, religion and gender relations in today's Iranian culture and society. In English.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Theory and Practice of Intercultural Competence
description: What is intercultural competence? What are its benefits in our globalized society? Through readings, discussions, videos and visuals students will learn the theory behind intercultural competence as well as practical aspects about gaining and honing the skills needed for IC. Students will experience how the implementation of IC enhances study, work and internships carried out both globally and domestically. Limited to 40 students. This course is open to all students. It is also the foundational course required of students participating in Brown's Certificate of Intercultural Competence.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Seminar in Language Pedagogy and Second Language Acquisition
description: This course prepares graduate students in modern languages to understand theories of language pedagogy and second language acquisition. Students will gain both practical knowledge to incorporate into everyday teaching as well as an understanding of which approaches to teaching might be more effective than others in various classroom contexts and why. Undergraduates may enroll with permission of the instructor.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intensive Introduction to Latin
description: This course offers a rapid introduction to the Latin language and grammar. As a one-semester introduction to material often covered in two semesters, this course carries two credit hours instead on one. The workload for this course is correspondingly heavy; students may expect an average of ten hours of homework—including memorization, practice, and preparation of vocabulary and grammar—per week. There are no prerequisites for this course.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Essentials of the Latin Language
description: Second course in an intensive two-semester approach to Latin. Special emphasis on developing facility in the rapid reading of Latin literature. No previous knowledge of Latin is required prior to taking this two course sequence.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Latin Literature
description: Introduction to Latin literature through intensive reading of major authors in prose and poetry with careful attention to grammar and style. Prerequisite: LATN 0100, 0200 or 0110 (or equivalent).
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LATN 0100, 0200 or 0110.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Tacitus
description: We read Book 11 (47-48 CE) during Claudius' reign as emperor, focusing on the downfall of Claudius' wife, Messalina, who plots to replace him with her lover, and his depiction of Claudius' censorship, especially the admission of Gallic citizens into the Roman Senate (and we compare Claudius' speech on this subject to the parts of the oration that are preserved on the Tabula Lugdunensis, a bronze tablet found in Lyon, France). We also read most of Book 15 (64-65 CE), with its reportage of Nero's reign, especially the Great Fire of Rome and the Pisonian conspiracy. We consider Tacitus' masterly style, historiographic methods, Tendenz, and an overarching question: how did the imperial system ever survive these regimes?
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Fortunatus
description: Wide reading in the occasional poetry of the most prolific writer of the early Middle Ages, attending to diction, meter, imagery, allusion, and paying special attention to the (homo- and hetero-) erotic pieces written to the poet's friends.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Plautus
description: Plautus' Menaechmi, Rudens, and Captivi are three Plautine masterpieces. We read at least two, and do so with as much understanding of archaic Latin and theatric convention as we can muster. Students are expected to be in command of Latin syntax and morphology. Plautine metrics are difficult: reading the Latin text aloud is essential. Aspects of performance are given attention: Plautus, himself an actor, wrote his plays to be performed; we, too, must give thought (if not practice) to the Plautine stage and how that affects our understanding. For comparison, we shall have performance readings of Shakespeare's Comedy of Errors and possibly Shinza the Barber (a Japanese Kabuki play). If it turns out that students have read any of the plays suggested here and prefer another, please let the instructor know as soon as possible—she will try to accommodate!"
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Latin Prose Composition
description: Review of the basic tenets of Latin syntax, composition, and style. English to Latin translation exercises will shore up composition skills, as we study the stylistic traits of seven Roman authors: Cato, Caesar, Cicero, Sallust, Livy, Seneca, and Tacitus. The course will proceed chronologically according to author. Class time will be spent on translation exercises and review, as well as the identification of the stylistic and syntactic characteristics of the seven authors under study.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Horace’s Odes and their Reception
description: We will read selections from Horace's Odes closely, with attention to the lyric traditions in which they were composed and the lyric traditions which they later helped constitute. In addition to questions of style, meter, voice, and history, we will also examine the commentaries, ancient and modern, which have accompanied readers of the Odes. Although the course is primarily aimed at graduate students in Classics, advanced undergraduates are also welcome to participate, as well as qualified graduate students in other humanities programs.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Linguistics
description: The ability to speak and understand a language involves having mastered (quite unconsciously) an intricate and highly structured rule-governed system. Linguists seek to model that rule system. This course introduces students to the areas of phonetics (speech articulation and transcription), phonology (the principles that govern how sounds are put together), morphology (the principles governing word structure), syntax (the rule system governing sentence structure), and semantics (the system that relates sentences to meanings).
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Playing with Words: The Linguistic Principles Behind Word Games and Puzzles
description: In this course, we explore the use of language in a domain which is fairly unlike ordinary communication: the use of language in wordplay, alternate languages, games, and puzzles. At one level, understanding aspects of linguistic theory can provide insight into the internal workings of these various forms of wordplay. On another level, wordplay and puzzles often intentionally subvert the grammar and other rules of ordinary language use and therefore can provide a unique lens into typically implicit grammatical knowledge speakers possess and deploy in all domains of language.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Constructed Languages
description: This course introduces students to the field of linguistics and language typology (the study of crosslinguistic variation and universals) through the project of creating their own constructed languages—conlangs. Students will learn about linguistic phenomena from a variety of diverse languages across the world, serving as inspiration for various aspects of their own conlangs. Broad topics include phonetics and phonology (the study of speech sounds and how they combine), morphology (the structure of words), syntax (the structure of sentences), semantics (how linguistics forms express meanings), historical linguistics (how language changes over time), and writing systems. We will also cover the history of the art of constructed languages. The course culminates in a descriptive sketch grammar of the new language, which will be gradually built up with regular assignments throughout the semester based on the topics discussed in class.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Evolution of Human Language
description: Where did the human capacity for language come from and why does language have the properties it does? We'll consider and evaluate several hypotheses for the biological and cultural evolution of language, drawing on evidence from emergent languages across modalities (spoken and signed), other species, genetics and language disorders, experimental methods, and computational models. This course has no pre-requisites and is appropriate for students new to linguistics and evolutionary theory as well as those with strong backgrounds in these areas.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Morphology
description: What are words? Is there evidence for them having internal structure? What is the relationship between what can intuitively be understood as "forms of the same word"? Is there a distinct word-building module of the grammar, or do words simply arise from the interaction of the syntax and phonology? These are the kinds of big-picture questions that morphologists ask. This course offers an in-depth introduction to the field of linguistic morphology, which investigates the form of "words"—whatever those are. We will investigate a number of morphological phenomena in a diverse sample of languages (e.g. allomorphy, suppletion, syncretism, inflection and derivation, morphomes, paradigmatic structure, lexicalism, bracketing paradoxes, the relationship between morphology and syntax/phonology, *ABA phenomena, etc.), culminating with an introduction to Distributed Morphology, a current and highly-influential theory of morphology and the architecture of the grammar.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LING 0100, CLPS 0300 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Sociolinguistics
description: This course is a comprehensive introduction to theoretical frameworks and methods of analysis in sociolinguistics. We will examine how language variation and change can reflect social structures, construct diverse social identities, and allow us to make sense of our surrounding social landscapes. We will first learn how linguistic variation corresponds to large-scale social categories like gender, age, ethnicity, and class. Then, we will turn our attention to how individual speakers use language to construct identities, portray stances, and achieve interactional goals. Throughout the course, we will consider how ideologies about linguistic variation have been used to invalidate particular ways of speaking and disempower speakers of these varieties, and how language can reflect, reinforce, or contest social inequalities.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LING 0100, CLPS 0300, 0030, COGS 0410, CLPS 0800, COGS 0450, CLPS 0340, ANTH 0800 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Bilingualism
description: This course explores key questions about the linguistic competence of bilinguals in comparison to monolinguals. Although many linguistic models assume a monolingual speaker, most of the world's population is bi- or multilingual. What does it mean to be bilingual rather than monolingual? How does knowing two languages shape linguistic behavior? What are the consequences of bilingualism for both language use and broader cognitive abilities? How do these realities align—or clash—with social attitudes and public policy? Drawing on data from a wide range of bilingual communities, students will engage with research from psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics to begin addressing these questions. Topics include language comprehension and production, acquisition, the mental representation of dual language knowledge, and the cognitive effects of bilingualism. We will also examine the social context of bilingualism, the advantages and disadvantages of bilingualism, and their implications for linguistic theory.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Screenwriting I
description: Screenwriting I introduces the fundamentals of short-form screenwriting through viewings, readings, exercises and assignments. Areas of particular focus include the short as a fully developed and distinctive work of art; visual storytelling, pacing and flow; effective screenwriting techniques, optimizing every word; articulating your personal voice and vision; creating structures that best suit your content and intentions. In class, we will review your writing, lookbooks and group presentations; view and discuss short films; discuss readings; and do writing exercises. Assigned readings include theory, essays, treatments and screenplays. Films will also be assigned for viewing outside of class. This course is limited to undergraduates. S/NC.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Literary Arts (AB), Modern Culture and Media (AB) or Theatre Arts & Perfomance Stu. (AB) programs.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Digital & Cross-Disciplinary Language Arts 1

Those with little or no prior interdisciplinary or digital media experience are welcome. Learning is through making, reading, discussion, group projects, collaboration, and practice-based research presentations: integrating anything from multimedia and multimodal writing, to text and image, text and audio, performance, translingual and audiovisual elements, computation, augmented reality, AI generation, language models (LLMs), or something we haven't even thought of yet. Enrollment limited to 17. S/NC.

title: Lilith’s Brood: Weird Women’s Writing; Writing Weird Women
description: In this class, we consider how the broad category of "genre fiction" has enabled a range of possibilities and weirdness in fiction written by women. Drawing from generic tropes including magical realism, speculative fiction, folklore, horror, and afrofuturism, in this hybrid seminar/workshop, we will investigate how women writers have explored and exploded generic limitations of the supernatural, spiritual, folkloric, and nonhuman. Using these works as models, we will draw on our own cultural myths, inspirations, and the creative wellspring of the natural world in order to experiment with short and longer form writing.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Place as Force: Worldbuilding in Realist Fiction
description: Setting is, perhaps, the most oft-neglected technical element, but in fact, the most powerful work uses time and place as antagonist, as benevolence, as character. This course will deepen your understanding of setting as force, and we will discuss its use in contemporary works of fiction, as well as your use of setting in your own work. We will, together with a map of the United States, create our own fictional American town: you will turn in one piece set in our town and one piece set in the place and time of your choice.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Script to Screen: Scene Work
description: This intensive script development and directing workshop is designed for students who have some proficiency in screenwriting, and little to no directing experience. Basic shooting and editing skills are helpful, or will be learned in the first half of the semester. The course aims to serve as a two-way bridge, opening screenwriting students up to the possibility of directing their work, while also investigating how acting and directing experiences, and workshopping material with actors, can inform future screenwriting. Activities include learning acting and directing techniques, scene analysis, writing and revising scenes, casting and working with actors, creating a scene through improvisation, and filming practice versions of scenes. Guests will join us for workshops and final reviews.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LITR 0110E, 0210E, 1010E, 1110U or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment limited to students in the Literary Arts (AB) program.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Generative Poetry Workshop
description: This intensive generative poetry workshop combines in-class workshops, reading and review assignments, craft talks, in-class writing exercises and course portfolios/packets. The in-class workshops will focus on work brought in for discussion and review and will also include in class writing workshops responding to prompts. The course is designed to encourage the generation of new poetry by students and to develop good reading practices to engender good poetry-writing craft.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Writers-in-the-Community Training & Residencies
description: This course will operate mostly "in the field." We will spend some weeks discussing pedagogical approaches to teaching creative writing in community settings. We will thereafter train in residence, observing a poetry residency at a local elementary school, with visits to other community settings as well (sites to be determined). We will continue to discuss pedagogy, classroom practices and management, administrator-writer relations, and all other necessary logistical planning throughout the semester. By week 7, students will engage in their own writing residencies in pairs or small teams, working in a community setting of their choosing (K-12 school, shelter, library, etc.).
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LITR 1010A, 1010B or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Memory’s Imagination
description: Taking inspiration from the autobiographical work of newly minted Nobel Laureate, Annie Ernaux, we will examine and produce works of fiction, creative narrative non-fiction and hybrid texts that cleave, in that good old double-sense, to personal experience and/or personal passions. Works by Marcel Proust, Virginia Woolf, James Baldwin, Michael Ondaatje, John Keene, Jessica Au and Svetlana Alexeivich will be on the menu to inform and inspire. Students can expect a substantial weekly reading load and should come to each class prepared to discuss the assigned texts and linked creative assignments.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LITR 0100A, 0110A, 0210A, 1010A, 1110Z, 1150M, 1151Q, 1152V, 1152Y, 1153A, 1153B, 1153C, 1153D, 2010A or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Creative Process Workshop
description: Creative Writing can be understood as a method of turning ideas, sounds, images, snippets, fragments, dreams, research -- and any and all of life's materials -- into fully realized literary works. The "work" of literary works is hidden when we read books and published authors, and thus our sense of how unique and wondrous work is achieved can be underdeveloped or perfectionistic. In other words, when we rely on only a reader's perspective to guide us as artists, it provides little to no sense of artistic path. This workshop is for writers of all levels to explore several works-in-progress in more depth. The result will be an enhanced relationship to the works (and to process) and to a lifelong and sustainable creativity. Becoming a more curious and helpful reader of others is another tangible and valuable outcome. Open to all.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LITR 0110H, 0210H, 1010H, 1110N, 1150B, 1151X, 1152E, 1152Y, 1153H, 2010A, 2010B, 2110O or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Conjuring God
description: Is there a place for capital-g God in contemporary fiction? If so, how might the concept of God help us explore our individual and collective search for meaning? And what might narratives about encounters with the divine tell us about the idiosyncrasies of belief (in God, in ideas, in the self)? As we read works by Albert Camus, Graham Greene, Shusaku Endo, Marilynn Robinson and Ursula Le Guin, among others, we'll discuss why writers still attend to notions of the sacred and divine decades after "the death of God."
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Reading and Making with Large Language Models
description: Large Language Models can be used to generate text with a facility that some of us hail as 'human-level.' Informed by theory – chiefly linguistic and language philosophical – this workshop seminar allows its participants to explore what we mean when we say that artificial intelligence reads and writes; and what is implied for our own processes of literary or language-art making when we agree or intend to read and write with (and/or against) such systems. Apart from its reading-informed discussion, the workshop will provide time and critique for its participants' projects, which will engage and experiment with the seminar-generated ideas and actual machine-learned techniques.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: MICRO-UTOPIAS
description: This special topics workshop/seminar explores our capacity as poets, writers, and multi-disciplinary artists to dialogue with the world around us through a socially engaged practice. During this course we will study utopian and dystopian literature, world-making poetry, theoretical frameworks, and a variety of social philosophies and creative practices that, in the words of Carol Becker, create micro-utopias: artistic interventions that "attempt to create physical manifestations of an ideal 'humanity' in an inhumane world." We will workshop and activate our creative ideas in a laboratory-like atmosphere. All art-makers are welcome. Be prepared to move, discuss, risk, play, theorize, and revise.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Temporal Entanglements: Writing Historical Fiction
description: "The past is never dead, it's not even past." – William Faulkner How do fiction writers go about creating historical narratives? If we use Saidiya Hartman's words as our starting point, that we live in a kind of "temporal entanglement," where the past, present and future, "are not discrete and cut off from one another," how might we write fiction that straddles this simultaneity? In this class, students will research and write a short work of historical fiction. We'll discuss research methods and sources, while developing supplementary materials, such as timelines, scrapbooks, and working bibliographies, that will serve to anchor our fictional texts. Students will also workshop their research-based stories with the class. In addition, we'll read a cross-section of historical fictions and study their various approaches. Students can expect a substantial weekly reading load on top of their individual
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: LITR 0210A, 1010A, 1150M, 1151Q, 1152T, 1152V, 1152Y, 1153A, 1153B, 1153C, 1153D or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Poetics of Mysticism
description: How does one speak the unspeakable? What rhetorical and rhythmical strategies can the poet use to write the ineffable? How can the practice of writing be used not only to document mystical experience, but to cultivate ceremonial attentiveness? This poetry workshop/seminar explores the intersection of mysticism and poetry. We will investigate how writers across traditions (Islamic mysticism, Christian mysticism, Neoplatonism, pantheism, atheistic mysticism) and eras use language to approach the divine. Through a combination of close reading, seminar-style discussion, and creative workshop, students will engage with core mystical concepts (apophasis, union, ecstasy, divine madness, love, the body, suffering, horror) and draw on these themes and strategies for inspiration into their own creative work.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Microfiction
description: Novels unravel years, decades, or even generations, while short stories culminate in singular, brilliant moments of epiphany. Short shorts, paradoxically, are heavily theme-based and thus tend to cover eternity. In this course, we will discuss the thematic underpinnings of micro fiction, and we will visit with the ways in which short shorts are structured differently from longer stories. We will examine the idea of pacing, as it is rendered in micro fiction, so that we might learn how to use such economy of words in our own micro fiction or traditional-length fiction. Each student will turn in at least three pieces of micro fiction or magical realism, and as final projects, you will revise two of these.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Writers on Writing
description: Offers students an introduction to the study of literature (including works from more than one genre) with special attention given to a writer's way of reading. This course will include visits to the course by contemporary writers, who will read to the class and talk about their work. Enrollment is limited to 30 students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Graduate Fiction
description: Advanced practice of the art: a writing seminar, limited to graduate students in Literary Arts. Emphasis is placed on developing a better understanding of the creative process, strategies and forms. Written permission required. S/NC.

title: Pedagogy Seminar
description: The Pedagogy Seminar examines ideas about teaching in a literary arts/creative writing environment. The pros and cons of the "workshop"-style will be discussed alongside alternative models, and general topics of exploration will include: creative process pedagogy, writing-to-learn, multi-genre approaches, uses of readings/research, and general classroom management. Designing an inclusive classroom and syllabus as well as exploring generative and innovative practices will be covered as well. A special emphasis will be on preparing students to feel confident and to explore a range of creative process issues. Personal writing as well as syllabus design will be expected.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Literary Arts (MFA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus
description: A slower-paced introduction to calculus for students who require additional preparation. Presents the same calculus topics as MATH 0090, together with a review of the necessary precalculus topics. Students successfully completing this sequence are prepared for MATH 0100. Prerequisite: MATH 0050 or written permission. May not be taken for credit in addition to MATH 0070 or MATH 0090. S/NC only.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: MATH 0050.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Math Teaching Fellows Program
description: The Math Teaching Fellows Program is a semester-long certificate program that provides UTAs with the skills and knowledge required to be an effective UTA in the Math Department. Admission into the program is by application only; participants will hold a UTA appointment in a Mathematics course approved by the Teaching Fellows Coordinators and must therefore be eligible for student employment at Brown during the term. Participants should have completed at least one of Math 0100, 0180, 0190, 0200, 0350, 0520, 0540.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Single Variable Calculus, Part I
description: An intensive course in calculus of one variable including limits, differentiation, maxima and minima, the chain rule, rational functions, trigonometric functions, and exponential functions. Introduction to integration with applications to area and volumes of revolution. MATH 0090 and MATH 0100 or the equivalent are recommended for all students intending to concentrate in the sciences or mathematics. May not be taken for credit in addition to MATH 0060 or MATH 0070. S/NC only.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Number Theory
description: An overview of one of the most beautiful areas of mathematics. Ideal for any student who wants a taste of mathematics outside of, or in addition to, the calculus sequence. Topics include: prime numbers, congruences, quadratic reciprocity, sums of squares, Diophantine equations, and, as time permits, such topics as cryptography and continued fractions. No prerequisites.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Linear Algebra
description: A first course in linear algebra designed to develop students' problem solving skills, mathematical writing skills, and gain facility with the applications and theory of linear algebra. Topics will include: vector spaces, linear transformations, matrices, systems of linear equations, bases, eigenvalues, and additional topics at instructor's discretion. Applications may include differential equations, difference equations, least squares approximations, and models in economics and in biological and physical sciences. MATH 0520 or MATH 0540 is a prerequisite for all 1000-level courses in Mathematics except MATH 1260 or MATH 1610. Recommended prerequisite: MATH 0100 or equivalent. May not be taken in addition to MATH 0540.

title: Linear Algebra With Theory
description: This course provides a rigorous introduction to the theory of linear algebra. Topics covered include: matrices, linear equations, determinants, and eigenvalues; vector spaces and linear transformations; inner products; Hermitian, orthogonal, and unitary matrices; and Jordan normal form. MATH 540 provides a more theoretical treatment of the topics in MATH 520, and students will have opportunities during the course to develop proof-writing skills. Recommended prerequisite: MATH 100, MATH 170, or MATH 190. [MATH 540 may not be taken in addition to MATH 520.]
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Analysis: Functions of One Variable
description: Completeness properties of the real number system, topology of the real line. Proof of basic theorems in calculus, infinite series. Topics selected from ordinary differential equations. Fourier series, Gamma functions, and the topology of Euclidean plane and 3-space. Prerequisite: MATH 0180, 0200, or 0350. MATH 0520 or 0540 may be taken concurrently. Most students are advised to take MATH 1010 before MATH 1630.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0520*, 0540* or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.* May be taken concurrently.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Graph Theory
description: This course covers important material about graph theory, such as spanning trees, network flow problems, matching problems, coloring problems, planarity, Cayley graphs, spectral theory on graphs, and Ramsey Theory. The emphasis will be on a combination of theory and algorithms. Depending on the instructor, connections to such fields as combinatorics, geometry, or computer science might be emphasized. Prerequisite: MATH 0180, 0200 or 0350 and MATH 0520 or 0540 are recommended.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0180, 0200 or 0350 and (MATH 0520 or 0540) or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Fundamental Problems of Geometry
description: This class discusses geometry from a modern perspective. Topics include hyperbolic, projective, conformal, and affine geometry, and various theorems and structures built out of them. Prerequisite: MA 0520, MA 0540, or permission of the instructor.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0520, 0540 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Cryptography
description: This course focuses on the mathematics underlying public key cryptosystems, digital signatures, and other topics in cryptography. A sampling of mathematical topics, such as groups, rings, fields, number theory, probability, complexity theory, elliptic curves, and lattices, will be introduced and applied to cryptography. No prior knowledge of these topics is assumed, nor is prior programming experience needed; any programming knowledge required will be covered in class.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0520, 0540 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Partial Differential Equations
description: The wave equation, the heat equation, Laplace's equation, and other classical equations of mathematical physics and their generalizations, discussion of well-posedness problems. The method of characteristics, initial and boundary conditions, separation of variables, solutions in series of eigenfunctions, Fourier series, maximum principles, Green's identities and Green's functions.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0520, 0540 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Mathematical Statistics
description: Frequentist and Bayesian viewpoints and decision theory principles. Concepts from probability, including the central limit theorem and multivariate normal distributions, and asymptotic estimates. Inferences from independent, identically distributed sampling: point estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and generalized linear models of regression.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 1210, 1610 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Abstract Algebra
description: A proof-based course that introduces the principles and concepts of modern abstract algebra. Topics will include groups, rings, and fields, with applications to number theory, the theory of equations, and geometry. Previous proof-writing experience is not required. MATH 1530 is required of all students concentrating in mathematics. It is strongly suggested that potential mathematics concentrators make MATH 1530 one of the first thousand level mathematics classes that they take.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 0520, 0540 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

description: Galois theory together with selected topics in algebra. Examples of subjects which have been presented in the past include algebraic curves, group representations, and the advanced theory of equations. Prerequisite: MATH 1530.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 1530 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Real Analysis II
description: A second course in real analysis, in this class we study measure theory and integration as well as Hilbert spaces. Among the many topics we study will be abstract measure and integration theory, Fourier transform, linear functionals and the Riesz representation theorem, compact operators, and the spectral theorem. The course may also include additional material of interest to the students and instructor.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MATH 1630, 1130 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Manifolds
description: Manifolds are a basic concept that unite ideas from linear algebra, multivariable calculus, geometry, and topology. Math and physics research require a familiarity with manifolds. Topics covered include the definition of a smooth manifold either as a smooth subset of R^n or as an abstract manifold, coordinating charts, and transition functions. The course will cover concrete examples: e.g. surfaces and 3-manifolds.Other topics include tangent vectors, vector fields, tensors, exterior algebra, differential forms, change of coordinates, Stokes' Theorem and the basics of De Rham cohomology.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: (MATH 0520 or 0540) and MATH 1530 and 1010 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Differential Geometry
description: Introduction to differential geometry (differentiable manifolds, differential forms, tensor fields, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles, connections, and Riemannian geometry), followed by selected topics in the field. Pre-reqs: MATH 2110 and undergraduates require permission from the instructor.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Algebraic Geometry
description: Complex manifolds and algebraic varieties, sheaves and cohomology, vector bundles, Hodge theory, Kähler manifolds, vanishing theorems, the Kodaira embedding theorem, the Riemann-Roch theorem, and introduction to deformation theory. Pre-reqs: MATH 2510 and MATH 2520 and undergraduates require permission from the instructor.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: MATH 2510*.* May be taken concurrently.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Real Function Theory
description: The basics of Hilbert space theory, including orthogonal projections, the Riesz representation theorem, and compact operators. The basics of Banach space theory, including the open mapping theorem, closed graph theorem, uniform boundedness principle, Hahn-Banach theorem, Riesz representation theorem (pertaining to the dual of C_0(X)), weak and weak-star topologies. Various additional topics, possibly including Fourier series, Fourier transform, ergodic theorems, distribution theory, and the spectral theory of linear operators.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.
