title: Television Studies
description: Introduces students to the rigorous study of television, concentrating on televisual formations (texts, industry, audience) in relation to social/cultural formations (gender, generational, and family dynamics; constructions of race, class, and nation; consumerism and global economic flows). That is, this course considers both how television has been defined and how television itself defines the terms of our world. Students MUST register for the lecture section, the screening, and a conference section. Open to undergraduates only.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Cinematic Coding and Narrativity
description: Introduces students to rigorous study of the structural and ideological attributes of cinema, concentrating on the dominant narrative model developed in the American studio system and alternatives to that model. Attention to film theory in relation to questions of representation, culture, and society. Students become conversant with specific elements and operations of the cinematic apparatus (e. g. camerawork, editing, sound-image relations) and how they produce discursive meanings. Open to undergraduates only.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to DJ Culture
description: Drawing on histories and subcultures of electronic dance music, alongside theories of sampling, mixing, remixing and postproduction, this practice-based course offers a basic introduction to DJ and production technologies as well as an exploration of world making tactics via the manipulation of sound and space. How do DJs manipulate sound to stitch together a unique sonic narrative? How is DJing itself a kind of theorizing through sound? Topics include the history of the DJ from the early 20th century to the rise of DJ-focused dance musics, from hip-hop to techno. Students will have hands-on experience with CDJs and throughout the semester, students will work on a series of short sound exercises and a final or collaborative project. There are no prerequisites for this class.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Transnational Cinemas in East Asia
description: This first-year seminar comparatively studies the forms and histories of East Asian cinemas in the context of transnationalism and globalization. As the notion of nation-state has increasingly been problematized, the concept of "national cinema," which frames cinematic works according to their countries of origin, has come into question. This course revisits this theoretical debate by exploring the transnational connections among different film cultures in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea. The course will emphasize as much the local diversities and specificities as the stylistic, generic, thematic, and industrial conjunctions across national/cultural boundaries. While surveying major genres and auteurs in East Asian cinemas, such as Wong Kar-Wai, Hou Hsiao-Hsien, Ozu, Kurosawa, Park Chan-wook and Bong Joon-ho, through the theoretical frameworks of nationalism, transnationalism, post-colonialism, and globalism, the course will particularly focus on the shifting representation of identities of gender,
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Experiments in NonFiction Film and Media
description: We live in a time of unprecedented access to both making and consuming media. Holding a creative practice offers a space to slow down, observe, and reflect. This course introduces students to creative practice as a way of seeing, sensing, and reflecting on the world. While work across mediums is welcome, we will focus on filmmaking not only as a technical skill, but as a mode of inquiry — a process of listening, experimenting, and developing one's creative voice. Students will engage in hands-on experimentation exploring nonfiction shapes experience, memory, and perception while drawing from critical theory to question binaries of theory and practice. By the end of the semester, students will complete several short experiments and one final nonfiction project that synthesizes both theoretical and personal insight into their own creative practice.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Let’s Get Physical: Histories and Theories of Fitness and Wellness
description: Did you know that the treadmill originated as a prison torture device? This course will examine the body and technology, as well as exercise and wellness cultures across media. Through readings in critical theory, media studies, gender studies, disability studies, and science and technology studies, students will explore the spaces and instruments of fitness, as well as the cultures that have emerged around them. Looking at a variety of texts, including treadmill patents and live-streamed Peloton classes, we will ask what the history of exercise tells us about gender, perceptions of health and disability, and our relationship to technology. Utilizing different research methods, including interviewing an Instagram fitness influencer and conducting autoethnography at the Nelson Gym, we will interrogate theories of "fitness," from eugenics up through contemporary wellness fads such as biohacking, polygenic embryo screening, and "Make America Healthy Again."
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Kiarostami: What is an Image?
description: In the history of cinema, a small number of directors have been treated as if their work stood for cinema itself. Abbas Kiarostami is one of these. Yet while his films foreground the act of cinema, they also address questions of reality to which the "neorealist" label cannot respond. To existing attempts to analyze his films in this light, we will add a principia domestica. Our question is this: how is it that the mystical, Islamic background from which Kiarostami invents is able to respond to current debates about reality in compelling, modern terms?
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MCM 0100, 0110, 0150, 0220, 0230, 0240, 0250, 0260, 1110 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Animatedness: History and Theory of Animation
description: This course explores the history and theory of animation through the notion of "animatedness," a concept raised by Sianne Ngai to describe a racialized feeling of being moved both physically and emotionally, an affect that is deeply rooted in the forms and techniques of animation. We will examine animation's historical development and stylistic possibilities, from the earliest stop-motion animations to the latest computer graphic techniques, exploring the aesthetics of animation as a fertile ground to interrogate the relationship between changing technological conditions and often-racialized bodily experience in modern society marked by mobility, fragmentation, and demarcation. It is also meant to give you a different way to think about the basic concepts in film history and theory, moving away from the assumption of an essentially photographic medium to consider different ways in which moving images are produced, received, and appreciated.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MCM 0150, 0220, 0230, 0240, 0250, 0260, 1110 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Experimental Video and Emerging Media
description: This production course explores experimental video and media practices that challenge conventional cinematic forms and modes of storytelling. Each week, we will engage with the aesthetic and critical dimensions of a range of experimental approaches, including essay films, video poetry, elemental and immersive media environments, video game documentaries, and forms of micro-cinema—such as internet memes and animated GIFs—as well as critical engagements with generative AI. Through hands-on workshops in video and image-making, alongside screenings and discussions, students will complete short creative assignments and develop a major final project. Guest lectures by invited artists and filmmakers will provide insight into current moving-image practices. The course will culminate in a group screening and exhibition at the MCM-Carriage House.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Activating the Archive: Contemporary Film Practice
description: This film and media production course explores historical and contemporary archives as sites of both artistic and critical intervention. Engaging with questions of inscription, memory, erasure, and historical re-imagination, students will examine how artists and filmmakers repurpose archival materials to craft counter-histories and speculative narratives. Through workshops in video and image-making, screenings, discussions, and guest lectures by invited artists and filmmakers, students will engage with archives as spaces for critical inquiry and poetic retrieval. Each student will select one or more archives to develop a major project that reinterprets, recontextualizes, or reimagines the retrieved material. The course will culminate in a final group exhibition and screening at the MCM Carriage House.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Theoretical Practice
description: Our course will examine the conceptual pair or binary opposition: "theory and practice" ("practice and t bheory"). Ubiquitous across the disciplines, arts, and sciences, in civic discourse and popular imaginaries, this couple is articulated as a pernicious hierarchy, fundamental critical insight, and stubbornly persistent ideology. Its theorists (also its practitioners) have elaborated its constitutive force, exposed its reifications, exploited its powers, and demystified its ideologies. Refigured and displaced, refused but persistently at work, the terms of this distinction have been aligned with myriad potent critical concepts: the abstract, intelligible, ideal, and subject ranged against the concrete, sensible, material, and object; mind versus body, thought versus experience. We'll query these accounts in readings ranging from Marx, Moten, and Spivak to Wilson, Althusser, Kornbluh, and de Kretser, emphasizing literary theoretical instantiations of the problem of a genuinely theoretical practice.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Biology of the Mind
description: In 1979 Frank Sulloway wrote a well-regarded biography of Freud, which maintained that the father of psychoanalysis never surrendered his first calling as a biologist. Indeed, Freud never stopped thinking of himself as a scientist who wished, as he put it, to "leave his psychoanalytic calling card" with the biologists. What does this mean? What happens to biology when it is retrofitted with an unconscious? We will examine various texts of Freud, Lacan, Canguilhem, Bergson, and Deleuze, among others and sort out their intricacies by reading them in relation to the paintings of Francis Bacon, films as The Cow (Merjui, 1969, the works of the bizarre architect, Patrick Geddes.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Punk: Notes on Artist Rage
description: In his seminal text Subculture: The Meaning of Style (1979), media theorist Dick Hebdige notes that punk subcultures present an indirect challenge to hegemony through noise and style as forms of interference. This seminar explores the music, fashion, film, literature and visual art of punk as a complex intersection of subculture, style and self-making; noise and disobedience; and collaboration and creativity in the face of annihilation. Since punk's arrival in the US and the UK in the 1970s, its subcultures and cultural productions have been associated with practices of dissent and refusal in the face of authoritarian political and cultural forces. Over the course of the semester, we attend to the unruly sounds, textures and manifestos of punk, with a particular emphasis on Black and Brown punk provocateurs, race, class and gender relations, collaboration, DIY practices, and creativity "underground."
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Body: Medieval Perspectives
description: In this course, we will explore bodies from a wide range of disciplines in medieval studies. The body has been always an object of imagination, literature, science, philosophy, and religion, it is the vehicle of both the divine and the profane, and it is at the center of debates on sexuality, gender identities, race, and politics. In this course, we look at how different views on the body and on sexuality developed and changed throughout the medieval period and how they influenced and were influenced by the religious doctrines, medical theories, and the intellectual environment of different groups of people. Finally, we will explore bodies both physical and metaphorical.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Health Systems Science II
description: This course will offer an overview of the critical issues in U.S. healthcare and public health policy. It will also provide future leaders in population medicine with a foundation for analyzing healthcare reform and public health efforts and for identifying the role of physicians in driving and shaping future policy reforms to improve the healthcare system and population health.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Science (GR CRT) or Medical Science (SCM) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: HSS III: Pop & Clinical Med II
description: This is the second semester of Population and Clinical Medicine, a two-semester course focused on the integration of population medicine and clinical practice. In this course, students will focus on topics integral to clinical medicine, but expand beyond the patient into the population and beyond. Given the importance of population health interventions for impacting the health of vulnerable and underserved patients, the course will focus on issues affecting these populations.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Science (GR CRT) or Medical Science (SCM) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the MD-ScM Combined Program or Remote Study / Study Abroad cohorts may not enroll.

title: Patient Care in Complex Systems II
description: This is the third of a 3 course sequence for Master of Medical Science students. Students will continue their study of both theoretical and practical aspects of healthcare through an interactive seminar series, continued service learning at their longitudinal community healthcare site, and completion of their community project. Seminar topics: care of vulnerable populations, environmental health, population health, new models of healthcare delivery, ethical issues in healthcare, whole-person health, cultural humility, complementary and alternative medicine, and patient advocacy. Students assessment includes: seminar participation, reflective essays, attendance at field work sites, assessment from community mentors, and quality of project and presentation. Pre Requisites: MED 2110 and MED 2120.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Science (GR CRT) or Medical Science (SCM) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Brain Sciences with Head and Neck Anatomy
description: This is a core course for the ScM in Medical Sciences degree, part of the Gateways program at Alpert Medical School. This course builds on 4 required prerequisite courses offered in the Fall Semester. In this course, students learn the integration of neuroanatomy, gross anatomy and basic science principles, and the application of these principles to clinical neurologic dysfunction. In the anatomy portion of this course, students learn about the functional and developmental anatomy of the head and neck. This study is aided by review of prosections of the head, neck and brain, and builds on anatomical structure and function learned in the fall semester. The neurobiology section is designed to acquaint students with the major structures and functions of the nervous system, building on cell physiology and introductory materials from the fall semester, and the application to clinical dysfunction.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MED 2140, 2150, 2160 and 2170.Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Science (SCM) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Microbiology and Infectious Disease
description: Microbiology and Infectious Disease is an integrated course that introduces the basic biological principles, pathogenesis and host response, disease presentation, epidemiology, control and treatment of parasites, viruses, fungi and bacteria that cause human disease. Emphasis is placed on the most clinically significant and best characterized pathogens in each group. The Microbiology component of the course explores the characteristics of disease-causing microorganisms, mechanisms of transmission, immunity, and how specific microbial pathogens cause disease. Microbial disease states in multiple organ systems are addressed in the Infectious Disease component of the course with a focus on common infectious diseases and their clinical presentation.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Science (GR CRT) or Medical Science (SCM) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Computational Medical Physics
description: The aim of the Computational Medical Physics course is to familiarize students with mathematical, statistical and computational techniques in Medical Physics and how they integrate at a systems level. Students will learn about the emerging field of Computational Medical Physics through the application of mathematical modeling, computer simulations and quantitative and data-intensive analyses to medical data towards enhancing the accuracy, safety and efficiency of patient care and providing an understanding of cancer research. Basic programming skills are expected.

title: Radiation Therapy Physics
description: This course will provide a comprehensive survey of basic radiotherapy physics, fundamental radiation therapy, and contemporary radiation therapy. The basic principles of radiotherapy treatment modalities, radiation detection, dose calibration methods, and image-based treatment planning will be reviewed. Topics to be covered include external beam radiation therapy (photons, protons, and electrons), brachytherapy, and special procedures. Image guidance methods will be discussed as well as patient and machine quality assurance.

title: Physics of Medical Imaging
description: The course provides the necessary physics background that underpins day-to-day medical imaging physics activities. It is aimed primarily at new entrants to the profession, but should be of benefit to postgraduate students, postdoctoral research workers, physicist-managers, representatives of allied commercial organizations and anyone wishing to deepen or re-establish their understanding of the physics of medical imaging. Overviews of specialized or research related topics, such as positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance spectroscopy are given.

title: Advanced Radiation Therapy
description: Advanced Therapy is meant to serve as a guided self-study of advanced / applied topics in radiation therapy with emphasis on current clinical usage. Optional topics include, but are not limited to, dose calculation algorithms, optimization techniques, deformable registration techniques, modeling within treatment planning systems, and treatment planning.

title: MR Imaging Technology, Ultrasound, and Interventional
description: This course will provide an introduction to magnetic resonance imaging scanner hardware, image acquisition methods used in the clinical setting for various contrast weightings, imaging of physiologic function, and image reconstruction methods. Causes and corrective measures for image artifacts will be discussed. Image-guided interventions for therapeutic purposes are becoming increasingly common as minimally-invasive treatments increase in popularity. The course will discuss some common methods used in interventional techniques with attention to the hardware and real-time image acquisition methods used for such therapies. An introduction to ultrasound imaging will be given which will include the physical principles of image formation, application of real-time techniques, Doppler methods for assessing blood flow, and ultrasound use in interventional procedures.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Medical Physics (SCM) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Iranian Cinema: History, Aesthetics, and Politics
description: Iranian cinema presents a striking paradox: while Iranians are often demonized globally, their films have garnered international acclaim for moral depth and humanistic vision. Drawing on Persian poetry, Sufism, and Islamic philosophy – while also influenced by modern movements like Italian neorealism and the French New Wave – Iranian cinema stands out for its sophistication and artistic originality. This course surveys its evolution from the 1960s to today, examining how major cultural and political events, from the 1979 Revolution to the Woman, Life, Freedom uprisings (2022–2023), have shaped cinematic expression. Students will explore themes of censorship, gender relations, sexualities, intimacy, love, and friendship, analyzing how filmmakers navigate moral and political constraints to create profound works of art. All films are subtitled; no knowledge of Persian required.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Strange Powers: Energy in the Modern Middle East
description: Do energy needs determine the shape of society, or the other way around? Is there such a thing as an energy transition, and if so, what drives such a change? What is the relationship between our ways of thinking and the energy regimes that have prevailed at different points in history? This course reframes the Middle East in modern global history (1750–present) from the perspective of different energy sources: water, wood, coal, oil, gas, wind, and sun. It highlights the production, circulation, and consumption of energy in processes of capitalist development; state construction (and destruction); imperialism, mass politics, and cultural difference; formation and maintenance of citizenship and migration regimes; and authoritarian rule. If global heating will render much of the Middle East uninhabitable by the end of the century, how did we get here and what does the future hold?
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: People & Ruins (Studio): Remapping Demolished Spaces & Narratives
description: How do Palestinians revive and rebuild their identities and remain resilient around the physical remains of their demolished and displaced heritage? This course is a multi-disciplinary studio that integrates digitization and visualization with political, historical, and planning analysis to explore contested spaces, uncover hidden histories, restore lost heritage, spatialize oral histories, and visualize the narratives and practices of Palestinian communities facing ongoing dispossession. The studio employs digital methods, mapping, filmmaking, and visual arts to generate geospatial data and conduct qualitative analysis of texts, plans, legislation, perceptions, oral histories, archives, and visual materials. We will engage with theories, studies, and data on restorative, decolonial, and Indigenous justice in urban environments, combining discourse and political analysis with spatial digitization and visualization to reveal the tragedy, resilience, and narratives of Palestinians, with a particular emphasis on Haifa.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12, 13, GM or GP.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The World “After Gaza”
description: Many observers, horrified by the ongoing carnage in Gaza, interpreted "the world's response" to Israel's war against Hamas after the attack of October 7, 2023, as a symptom for an end of an era in international relations. Taking these observations seriously and critically, this seminar asks what this international order was – or was imagined to be – and why the war in Gaza is seen to epitomize this order's dismantling. While making Gaza the perspective from which this international order, and its image, will be studied, the seminar will focus on three key concepts: Holocaust, Genocide, and Settler Colonialism. We will examine how each concept is used to make sense of the violence in Gaza, to conceive the international order whose end Gaza marks, and to recognize the dismantling of this order, or its image.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

The course continues on an integrative skills approach and aims to develop language skills, within a framework of specific topics and functions. The course objectives are to enable students to perform a range of tasks, master a minimum core vocabulary and acquire knowledge and understanding of various forms of Greek culture.

It aims to enhance language skills within a variety of registers and themes; enable the students to master, use and understand effectively essential linguistic structures; examine a variety of expressive forms within an authentic cultural context.

title: Advanced Modern Greek
description: A continuation of MGRK 0500. Students who have not taken the previous sequence may take a placement test, after consultation with the instructor. The course aims to promote range, accuracy and fluency and enable students to develop ease and spontaneity with the language. Authentic materials drawn from a range of sources inform the content of the course and include films, literature, media, testimonies, music and internet based sources. The development of transcultural competence will be an essential component of the course.

title: In Other Words: Translating Greece
description: This is an advanced undergraduate seminar that will offer students the opportunity to build on their linguistic, cultural and critical literacies, by translating from Greek into English. Over the course of the semester we will be thinking critically about texts, their ideological, historical and social coordinates and their embedded discourses of Greekness, community, diglossia, identity and gender, among others. In addition to translating from Greek into English, we will read and discuss essays on translation, in order to consider in an informed way the issues (untranslatability?) and types of decision making associated with the practice of translation.

title: Modern Greek for Classicists and Archaeologists
description: This graduate level course promotes the acquisition and further refinement of the necessary translingual and transcultural skills to prepare students in the fields of Classics and Archaeology to carry out research in Greece and Cyprus. In addition, it involves training in linguistic skills that will enable students to study closely a range of texts of relevance to these disciplines. Primary emphasis will be on the development of reading, oral and aural skills using a variety of text and web based materials, of discipline specific content but also in professional and other communicative contexts of cultural currency.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Management and Implementation in Public and Non-Profit Organizations
description: How and when can organizational leaders and staff become engines of policy and social change? How do the policies that elected officials, courts, and bureaucrats promulgate get put into practice? What affects whether those policies get put into practice? What affects whether those policies produce expected changes? This course is designed to help students identify and manage core challenges facing policy development, implementation, and sustainment in public organizations.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Public Affairs (MPA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Policy Problems of the 21st Century: Social Policy
description: This course provides a forward-looking analysis of public policy and inequality with a focus on the United States. It examines eight intertwined issue areas that any effort to reduce inequality must confront: 1) job quality and "bad jobs"; 2.) place winners and place losers; 3.) work, family, and policy; 4.) the supply of affordable housing and housing insecurity; 5.) climate threats and inequality 6). criminal justice: the school to prison pipeline; 7) the digital divide, algorithms, and inequality; 8) immigration. In each, we pay special attention to how racial and ethnic, and gender inequalities interact with these policy domains to reinforce inequality. The focus of the class is on the United States but in each of these domains we will draw comparisons from different parts of the world to understand how the United States is similar or different.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Policy Problems of the 21st Century:  State Law, Policy, and Advocacy
description: This section of Policy Problems of the 21st Century examines the changing role of states in the American system – the ways in which states are simultaneously limited in their ability to respond to certain social challenges, but increasingly empowered and expected to engage in other spheres of policymaking. After reviewing the fundamentals of state policymaking, we will focus on four substantive areas: environmental justice; housing policy; constitutional and civil rights; and health care. We will find throughout the course that these substantive areas overlap in complex ways at the individual and societal level. During the semester you will engage in group discussions, debate and roleplaying exercises, complete two written assignments, and prepare a final "State Law, Policy and Advocacy Project" on a subject of your choosing. Readings will include: a policy textbook, Deborah Stone's Policy Paradox; an ethnography, Desmond's
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Policy Problems of the 21st Century: Digital Peacebuilding
description: Digital Peacebuilding examines the policy challenges encountered in fostering peace within and among states in the Twenty-First Century. The course considers the utility of various peacebuilding interventions (e.g., foreign intervention, foreign aid, diplomacy, ceasefires and peace treaties, peacekeeping, courts, and elections), and the integration of digital technologies (e.g., artificial intelligence, virtual reality, cryptocurrencies, drones, satellites, crowdsourcing, and social media platforms) in these interventions.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Global Environmental Policymaking
description: Global environmental policymaking has a mixed record. In this course, we examine three stages of the policy process --- identifying problems, negotiating solutions, and implementing agreements --- to explore the conditions that lead to effective governance. We will ask: under what circumstances do countries negotiate treaties to resolve environmental problems, and when are these agreements effective? Our cases include plastics, whaling, ozone depletion, and especially global climate change. We will also focus on learning to write for policy audiences.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Public Policy and Politics in Partisan Times
description: This course explores the causes and consequences of partisan polarization, focusing on the impact of polarization on the development and implementation of American national policy. The course examines both historical and contemporary examples of successful and unsuccessful policy-making in such a climate, as well as the role of effective leadership and political entrepreneurship in the promotion of policy that can build wide support and overcome the barriers to adoption.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Public Affairs (MPA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: GIS and Public Policy
description:
This seminar presents an introduction to the theory and practice of social science Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as applied to public policy analysis. We will cover a variety of topics, such as the geographical basis of policy issues, spatial mapping, and use of ArcGIS software to study a wide range of policy issues. The course will involve discussions, hands-on computer laboratory exercises, take-home problem sets and a Practical Exam.
The goals of the class are: 1) learning how to use GIS software and techniques, 2) database development and editing 3) spatial modeling techniques, and 4) using GIS to study policy issues.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Public Affairs (MPA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Women and Nations
description: See the linkage between the security and situation of women and the security and situation of the nations in which they live. Understand the roles women play in world society as producers, reproducers, agents of cultural continuity and change, and to render women "visible" in international and national affairs. Explore in greater depth women's choices about education, family, and work in the developing world, and how these affect and are affected by national and international forces and influences.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Public Affairs (MPA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Policy in Action Project
description: The Policy in Action experience is designed to provide a rigorous and practical immersion in dealing with a real policy issue in a domestic or global community-based or institutional setting. The course focuses on experiential learning and creative problem-solving. Teams of students address real-world, complex, contemporary problems, explore policy and practice-based solutions, identify strategies for addressing feasibility concerns, and recommend future approaches to external partner organizations. Students conduct research to understand contemporary problems and issues and develop policy and practice-related solutions to address these issues and/or enhance an organization's capacity.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Public Affairs (MPA) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: 1000 Years of Listening
description: This course aims to introduce you to a variety of music and a range of ways of listening to, and thinking, talking, and writing about music. The majority of music dealt with will be drawn from the so-called "Classical" repertory, from the medieval period to the present day. We cover canonic favorites, but we will also explore music you may have never have encountered before. We will become familiar with the technical workings of music, while at the same time thinking about—and rethinking—some of the stories we tell about the history of Western art music. This is a tradition which has kept some musics alive across centuries, but it has also excluded many voices. In this class, we will think about the idea of the musical canon, what it offers, and how it might change.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: MEME Ensemble: The Rap Cypher & Freestyle Performance
description: The rap cypher is more than rappers freestyling (improvising) in a circle. It is a circle of possibility, a circle of immediate knowledge production, a circle of deep listening and a circle of unconventional citation. In this ensemble, we will develop a freestyle practice by investigating composer Pauline Oliveros' Deep Listening Theory inside the context of hip-hop through lyrical and musical analysis. Through research and improvisational practice, we will explore these questions: What can I "hear" in the beat, in the room, in the present cypher that I can converse with / build upon? How can I use imperfection to my advantage? Classes will focus on deep listening analysis of music and videos, discussion of readings, freestyle exercises, and rap cypher workshops. The course culminates in in a live public rap cypher.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Music Theory
description: An introduction to musical terms, elements, and techniques. Topics include notation, rhythm and meter, intervals, scales, chords, melody writing, harmonization, and form. Students will develop their musicianship skills, including sight-singing and keyboard, in labs which meet twice weekly. No prior musical experience is necessary. MUSC 0400A or 0400B may fulfill part of the theory requirement for the music concentration. Enrollment limited to 30. Permission granted based on questionnaire given in first class. Preference given to lower-level students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Theory of Tonal Music I
description: Intensive study of the building blocks of tonal music traditions including western and popular music with focus on melody, harmony, counterpoint, keyboard skills, ear training, sight-singing from musical notation, and composition. Prior keyboard experience helpful but not required. A required placement exam is administered at first class meeting. Students who do not have experience reading music notation should take MUSC 0400 prior to MUSC 0550. MUSC 0550 is a prerequisite to many music courses and is a requirement for the music concentration.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Theory of Tonal Music II
description: The objective of Music 560 is to advance the student's knowledge of the theory and practice of tonal music, with an emphasis on more advanced techniques of voice leading and harmony, such as modal mixture and chromaticism. Labs focus on mastery of related keyboard, score-reading, and aural skills. Form of tonal music will be studied, including sonata form.Exercises include four-part harmonization, analysis and composition in a variety styles and genres. Compositional assignments are given in order to encourage musical creativity and to illuminate theoretical concepts in the process. A more substantial final compositional project is due at the end of the semester and will be performed in class. MUSC 0560 is designed as part of a year-long comprehensive course in the theory of tonal music. Prerequisite: MUSC 0550 or permission of the instructor.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: MUSC 0550.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Jazz and Pop Harmony
description: For students with knowledge of the rudiments of music, including scales, intervals, key signatures, rhythm, and meter. Keyboard skills strongly recommended. Intensive study of chord scales, chord progressions, modulation, voice leading, melody writing, harmonization, reharmonization, chord symbols, and lead sheet construction. Lab sessions will focus on ear training, keyboard exercises, and sight singing. Emphasis will be on the vocabulary of jazz theory.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: MUSC 0550.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Chorus
description: Half credit each semester. A practical study of choral literature, techniques, and performance practice from Gregorian chant to the present, offered through rehearsals, sectionals, and performance. Enrollment is by audition, based on voice quality, experience, and music-reading ability. Instructor permission required.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Orchestra
description: Half credit each semester. A practical study of the orchestra repertory from Bach to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Students will be notified of audition results within the first seven days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists. May be repeated for credit.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Wind Symphony
description: Half credit each semester. A practical study of the wind band repertory from Mozart to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists. Instructor permission required.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Jazz Band
description: Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.

title: Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble
description: A dynamic introductory course on drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora. Students learn to perform diverse types of African music, including Ewe, Akan, Ga, and Dagomba pieces on drums, bells, and shakers. No prerequisites. May be repeated for credit. Enrollment limited to 15. Instructor permission required.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: World Music Ensemble
description: This ensemble focuses on global percussive and song traditions, especially those of the African diaspora (based on instructor's vast musical experiences). Here western instrumentalists fuse with traditional musicians from every culture: bongo, gyil, ukulele, tabla, etc. Students will grow and develop their musical skills by learning new techniques on their own instrument, exploring a range of repertoire representing genres such as highlife, reggae, salsa, afrobeat, Afro-jazz, and global fusions. There will be unique opportunities to work on improvisation taking influence from Steve Reich, Tito Puente, Randy Weston, Hugh Masekela, Paul Simon, Miriam Makeba, Ghanaba, and Milton Nasimiento.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Javanese Gamelan
description: Half credit each semester. Instruction, rehearsals, and performances in the gamelan music of Java, on instruments owned by the department. No prerequisites. Enrollment limited to 18 students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Old-Time String Band
description: Half course each semester. Instruction and ensemble playing. Music taught by ear. American (southern Appalachian Mountain) traditional music on violin (fiddle), 5-string banjo, mandolin, and guitar. Enrollment limited to 20 students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Chamber Music Performance
description: Half credit each semester. The practical study of the literature of chamber music through participation in a small ensemble. Regular rehearsals, coaching by department staff, and performances are required. Enrollment is by audition. Students will be notified of audition results within the first ten days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists. May be repeated for credit.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Tonal Counterpoint
description: The contrapuntal techniques of the 18th century with emphasis on music of Bach. Written exercises in and analysis of several genres including fugue. Prerequisite: MUSC 0560 or permission of instructor.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 0560 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Analysis of Romantic Musics
description: This course introduces analytical approaches to both 19th-century Western European art music and more recent genres that have been influenced by its harmonic vocabulary and aesthetic aims. Building on students' previous study of music theory, the course comprises three broad units, respectively centered around theories of Romantic form, chromatic harmony and voice-leading, and rhythm and meter.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 0560, 0570 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Seminar in Composition
description: This is a seminar-based course with a creative component focusing on specific compositional techniques such as writing transitions and motivic development, and writing for specific kinds of ensembles. These techniques are applicable to all kinds of music, from concert music to popular genres. The course will also address aesthetic issues, trends and influences and how they affect living composers' individual voices. Besides studying notated repertoire from the concert tradition, we will also examine approaches to film scoring, improvisation, and environmental sound worlds outside of the traditional concert hall.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 0560* and 1100 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.* May be taken concurrently.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Projects in Composition
description: This is a practice-based composition course in which students work on advanced projects in composition. Students meet in small groups with the instructors for individualize feedback and group discussion on their projects. Students meet in the group seminar meetings to present work and to listen to and discuss work by other composers. This course gives preference to students who are completing honors thesis or capstone senior projects in music composition. Students can take this before their senior year but must have taken MUSC 1110 previously.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 0550 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Recording and Sound Design Techniques
description: Music 1200 is a rigorous study of music production techniques taught in parallel with topics in psychoacoustics. Students will create original studio work while developing listening and technical skills for audio production. Technical topics include recording, signal processing and mixing software, microphone technique, and sound engineering fundamentals. Class size is limited and some prior experience with digital audio workstations is expected. Preference will be given to students who have successfully completed MUSC 0200 and are active in the music department. Admission is determined by an entrance questionnaire completed at the first class meeting.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Music and Disability
description: This course introduces students to key concepts in the interdisciplinary field of disability studies for investigating embodied variations in musical practices. Through course discussions, lecture, assignments, and readings, students will learn how to analyze musical texts through a disability lens, asking what we can know and learn about disability through music and sound. Likewise, students will also examine how disabled bodyminds challenge ideas about musicality, beauty, skill, virtuosity, performance, and creativity. Topics covered will include sociocultural models of disability; disability aesthetics and musical representation; racial, gendered, and classed intersectional analysis; blindness, deafness, and Deaf culture; prosthesis and technology; aging and old composers, performers, creators, and listeners; history of eugenics; trauma studies, and depression. Students interested in issues of disability in music cultures, performance, composition, music industry, and advocacy are encouraged to enroll. All are welcome.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Audio Techniques
description: This course will focus on developing and reinforcing technical skills, musical concepts, and critical listening abilities associated with the practice of composition in electronic/computer music studios and software. These studies will be tied to a broad range of aesthetic approaches and discussions of sound processing, synthesis, spatialization, and recording techniques. Through projects and focused study, students will expand their knowledge and craft, and will provide each other with a forum for exploring their creative studio work. Class size is limited. MUSC 1200 is a prerequisite, and preference will be given to students who have also taken other music technology courses.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 1200 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Music Industry
description: This course offers an overview of the American music industry, tracing key developments from its inception to the present day. Through historical, analytical, and practical approaches, students will explore how the industry continues to evolve in response to technological innovation, cultural shifts, and market forces. Key topics include production, distribution, copyright, platformization, business operations, and the industry's global influence. The course also considers the social and cultural dynamics that have shaped musical categories and industry practices. By the end of the course, students will gain a foundational understanding of the structures, challenges, and opportunities that define the contemporary music industry.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Rap Songwriting
description: Advanced Rap Songwriting is a production seminar that builds on the foundations established in "Intro to Rap Songwriting" and is designed for students seeking to refine their craft as lyricists and pursue more experimental rap songwriting forms. Through deep listening sessions, weekly workshops, and conversations with guest artists and scholars, students will explore experimental techniques in rhythm, rhyme and flow; study a range of conceptual and narrative songwriting frameworks; and experiment with collaborative approaches to composition. Students will be expected to produce a portfolio of original works over the semester and to engage critically with their peers' projects through structured workshops.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 1240R or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Genius of Bach
description: An examination of the life and work of Bach, his vocal, orchestral, keyboard music, including its place in German society, views of his contemporaries and explanation of his performance venues, manuscript and publishing history.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Beethoven: Work, Biography, and Afterlife
description: By the 20th century latest, Ludwig van Beethoven became the greatest icon in music history. His presence extends beyond the realm of classical music into history, politics and popular culture, which celebrates him as the embodiment of the humanistic artist figure. This course examines Beethoven in a field of tension between biography, work and contemporary history. The musical work always in focus, it traces his development from a young piano virtuoso writing for his own performances to the creator of late, highly abstract spiritual works that completely leave the realm of "performance music". Alongside a study of his highly dramatic life and spheres of influence, we will examine his early works and trace the development of his musical language within the different Genres.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Jazz Composition Seminar
description: This is a seminar with a strong creative component that explores the art of jazz composition. We will explore a wide range of compositional techniques, listen to and analyze examples, and directly apply the studied theory to composition assignments for small and larger jazz ensembles. Please bring your instruments, as in each session, we will play our works live and then discuss and reflect on them collectively. The goal is to develop a profound understanding of both foundational and advanced jazz composition methods and accrue a wealth of written material that serves as an ideal springboard for the further development of your personal artistic voice. Music proficiency is required.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: MUSC 1570, 0630, 0570, 0550 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Text-to-Music: Writing for the Voice
description: The voice has held a special place in music composition for millennia. As an instrument which emerges directly from the body, and conveying extra-musical meaning via text, the voice is unique in its ability to create drama, engender narrative, and address corporeality in sound. In this course, students will engage with the many modes in which the voice has been utilized in western classical music, from canonical forms such as opera, lieder/chansons, choral writing and narration to ancient forms such as chant and organum, as well as more recent innovations including extended techniques, electronic augmentation, and AI vocal models, all while exploring their own compositional technique for the instrument. This course will start as a seminar consisting of group analyses of vocal music, before shifting to a studio environment engaging in the critique of original work by students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Women in Music
description: This course comprises a chronological survey of female composers and music creators from the ninth century to the present day. This will include the study of many pieces of music by women, accompanied by readings addressing the social, economic, cultural, and political circumstances that surrounded their composition. Additional readings address the larger context for women's composition and its reception over time as well as the development of a feminist perspective in music scholarship.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Choral Conducting
description: An introduction to the art of conducting, with emphasis on choral training. A study of the relationship of gesture to sound will be combined with a survey of the choral repertoire, beginning with Gregorian Chant and covering renaissance motets, masses and madrigals, Baroque works with instruments, excerpts from Mozart's vespers, 19th- century Romantic partsongs, and selected 20th-century. Issues of basic vocal production, warm-ups, rehearsal planning, editing, programming and concert production will also be included. Prerequisite: MUSC 0400 or 0550. Written permission required. May be repeated for credit.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Black Atlantic Musics in Rhode Island
description: When we talk about musics of the African diaspora, we often think first about "roots" – where musics originate. But what happens when we look more closely at the complex "routes" that characterize the history and present of the African diaspora, and the development of Black musical traditions worldwide? Using Paul Gilroy's framework of "the Black Atlantic" (and at times critiquing it), this seminar-style class will delve into various Rhode Island-based, local manifestations of Afro-Black music-making – from the Nuyorican hip-hop technology nexus to the Afro-Brazilian martial art of capoeira to the melancholic Cabo Verdean morna – as a lens through which to study global processes of sonic racialization, colonial/imperial musical assemblage, and trans-diasporic creativity. In this course, we will open ourselves to aesthetic and intellectual encounter with the sonic traditions of local Black diaspora communities -- and their practitioners.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble
description: Students with experience in African and related musical traditions perform drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora. Focus on a more challenging repertoire with emphasis on multi-part, lead, and improvisational playing. Prerequisite: audition. May be repeatable for credit. Instructor permission required. Enrollment limited to 15 students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Music and Identity
description: From 19th-century European nationalism to 20th-century American multiculturalism, people have used music to affirm their identities. Drawing on anthropological and sociological theory, we examine the variety of connections between music and identity in several case studies. We consider the possible contributions of music to cross- cultural understanding, and discuss the ethics of musical border- crossing.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Sound Studies
description: Explores sound studies through readings of exemplary texts and discussions of the key debates that enliven this interdisciplinary field of inquiry. Drawing on philosophical, musicological, anthropological, and other kinds of writings, it explores issues like the way that relations between sound, noise, silence, and music have formed in different cultures and different historical periods; ideological structures that determine the place of sound in artistic practice and in everyday life; the power relations that are implicated in the design of local soundscapes; and the place of aural perception within the sensorium, among other potential topics. Enrollment limited to graduate students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Composition Seminar
description: A forum for graduate composers to share and critique current projects. Visiting artists and analysis of relevant outside repertoire will augment the group and one-on-one meetings. Enrollment is limited. Written permission required. May be repeated for credit.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Composing and Improvising with Real-time Systems
description: This seminar will explore the use and creation of interactive computer music systems from the point of view of the performer/programmer. Using improvisation as a starting point, we will explore the aesthetics and philosophy of performance, designing real-time systems in MaxMSP that enhance the relation between action and event using network strategies.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Seminar In Sonic Practice
description: This studio and seminar course provides an exploration of contemporary sonic practice, facilitates the development of sound-based creative work, and encourages a critical approach to producing work in the field. Through discussion, reading, listening exercises, independent research, creative production and critiques, we will examine a number of intersecting areas of sonic practice including sound as a cultural, environmental, and artistic medium, phonography, sound installation, mobile audio, noise as strategy and material, linguistic and other sonic narrative structures. Students will develop sound-based pieces individually and in groups which function as creative research into the subjects areas of the course.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Dawnland Explorations: A Community-Engaged Survey of Native New England
description: Building reciprocal social relationships is essential for many Indigenous cultures and is often a prerequisite for taking part in community-engaged scholarship. In this experiential learning course, students will learn about the cultures and traditions of Dawnland peoples by travelling to culturally significant locations to connect with and learn from local Native communities. Through these excursions and conversations, students will begin to cultivate relationships that will enable them to design and implement mutually beneficial projects that deepen the understanding of the cultural traditions, histories, political experiences, and contemporary knowledge of Native American and Indigenous peoples and enhance student understanding and learning. Students in this class will utilize their skills and resources to partner with a Native collaborator on a jointly defined, service-based project.

title: Critical NAIS Capstone Course
description: This seminar serves as the capstone course for the Critical NAIS concentration, providing seniors the opportunity to share their research; reflect on what the field of NAIS is (and is) becoming; and consider how their work relates to the field as a whole. This seminar is not intended to develop a monolithic understanding of the field, but to explore the range of problems, methodologies, trajectories of inquiry and political aims across different kinds of NAIS scholarship. To gain a specific sense of these various approaches, we focus on scholarship-in-progress, building the syllabus based on areas of interest and expertise, finalized in a capstone project, practicum, internship or thesis. As the culmination of the concentration, the capstone may take the form of a research paper, project, and/or engaged experience or internship accompanied by a write up (thesis, report, digital product)
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ETHN 1200K, 1890H or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the Crit Native Amer & Indigenous (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience
description: This course will introduce students to the broad field of computational neuroscience through a combination of lectures, readings, and hands-on assignments. Historical perspectives will be explored and compared with modern approaches, with the aim of providing a broad understanding of this multidisciplinary approach to understanding the brain and nervous system. A key theme will be a focus on the central role that models play in framing scientific questions about neural systems and circuits. There are no prerequisites, but students should be prepared to learn basic programming and computational skills.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Principles of Neurobiology
description: A lecture course covering fundamental concepts of cellular and molecular neurobiology. Topics include structure of ion channels, synaptic transmission, synaptic development, molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity, learning and memory and neurological diseases. Prerequisite: NEUR 0010. Strongly recommended: BIOL 0200 or equivalent.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 0010 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Neurotechnology: Molecular Tools and Methods for Neurobiology
description: New tools are transforming Neurobiology, both in the way experiments are being done and the questions they are addressing. New methods of observation and analysis are enhancing our understanding of the complex workings of the brain. This course is unique in helping students become critical thinkers about choosing the right toolset for different neuroscience questions at both the systems and molecular levels. We will also examine how new molecular tools are developed and evolve to address fundamental questions about how our brain. In many ways, neurotechnology, new methods, and molecular tools open the way for new discoveries in neuroscience. Course is geared towards neuroscience, biomedical engineering, biology and others. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section on how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 0010 and 1020 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory
description: Exploration of learning and memory from the molecular to the behavioral level. Topics will include declarative and procedural memory formation and storage, associative and non-associative learning, cellular and molecular mechanisms for learning, and disorders affecting learning and memory. Examples will be drawn from numerous brain areas and a variety of model systems, including humans. Students will gain experience interpreting experiments from primary literature. Prerequisite: NEUR 1020.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 1020 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Developmental Neurobiology
description: The course will explore core concepts of developmental biology in the context of the developing nervous system. Topics will include: neuronal specification, cell migration, axon guidance, synapse formation, and neural plasticity. Students will gain experience with the primary literature and learn about cellular and molecular mechanisms of brain development and the tools and model organisms used to study them. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section on how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 0010 and 1020 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Non-Neuronal Brain
description: This undergraduate course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the role and function of glial cells, the non-neuronal cells that comprise half of our nervous system. Glia, once considered merely supportive cells, are now recognized as critical players in brain development, homeostasis, and neurological disorders. This course will explore the various types of glial cells, focusing on central nervous system glia, their structure and distribution, molecular characteristics, and their interactions with neurons and each other. Additionally, the course will cover recent advances in glial cell research and their implications for brain function and disease. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section for information about how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 1020 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Experimental Neurobiology
description: Intensive laboratory experience in neuroscience appropriate for students with basic background in Neurobiology. Learn and employ the classical neurophysiological techniques of extracellular recording, intracellular recording and receptive field mapping using a variety of animal species. Experiments will include recording of sensory signals in the cockroach leg; frog sciatic nerve and sciatic nerve/muscle preparation and intracellular recording of neurons in Aplysia. Instruction on and practice of effective science writing is another component to this course. Labs are supplemented by informal lectures. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section for information about how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 0010 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Neural Computation in Learning and Decision-Making
description: Your brain is constantly making decisions, receiving feedback about those decisions, and learning from that feedback. In this course we will examine the neuroscience underlying these processes from a computational perspective. The course will involve reading scientific papers from cognitive neuroscience, building and testing the computational models that have been developed to synthesize this literature, and, as a final project, extending an existing model of learning or decision making and characterizing its behavior. A primary goal for the course is to develop the tools and motivation to translate verbal theories of behavior into formal and testable computational models. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section on how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 0010 and 1030 or CLPS 0400, 0040, PSYC 0470 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Diseased Brain: Mechanisms of Neurological and Psychiatric Disorders
description: The goals of this course are to illustrate what basic science can teach us about neurological disorders and how these pathologies illuminate the functioning of the normal nervous system. Consideration will be given to monoallelic diseases (e.g. Fragile X Syndrome, Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy and Tuberous Sclerosis) as well as genetically complex disorders, such as Autism, Schizophrenia and Alzheimer's Disease. Emphasis will be on the cellular and molecular basis of these disorders and how insights at these levels might lead to the development of therapies. Prerequisites: NEUR 1020. BIOL 0470 suggested.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 1020 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Neurobiology of Love
description: The goal of this course is to explore the underlying neurobiological principles of love and attachment. Topics include the relevant brain areas, the role of sensation and perception in love and attachment; how love and attachment influence action and behavior; plasticity and learning in these systems; and relevant neurodiversity related to love and attachment. You will gain a deeper understanding of concepts and principles that apply throughout the brain. You will gain experience with primary literature and learn about the relevant experimental techniques. There will be an emphasis on how the neurobiology of love is portrayed in the popular press. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section for information about how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: NEUR 1020 and 1030 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Deep Learning in Neuroethology
description: Critical readings class will examine neural mechanisms for natural behavior (neuroethology) through reading classic studies and following current research. The course will emphasize the application of deep learning methods to movement patterns, spatial orientation, and social communication. DeepLabCut is one of several new programs that empower students and researches to take advantage of deep learning methods for behavioral neuroscience. The course will teach how to replace single-parameter data analysis with deep learning methods to identify underlying patterns Prerequisites are Introductory Neuroscience (NEUR0010) and prior training in Matlab or computer programming languages. DO NOT REQUEST AN OVERRIDE FOR THIS COURSE. Please see the Class Notes section for information about how to gain enrollment into this course.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Graduate Proseminar in Neuroscience
description: See Graduate Pro-Seminar In Neuroscience (NEUR 2010) for course description.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology II
description: This course continues the investigation of molecular and cellular approaches used to study the CNS from the level of individual genes to the control of behavior. Topics include patterning of the nervous system, generation of neuronal diversity, axonal guidance, synapse formation, the control of behavior by specific neural circuits and neurodegenerative diseases. Enrollment is limited to graduate students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Neuroscience (PHD) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: NeuroPracticum
description: Intensive laboratory experience appropriate for graduate students with basic background in cellular and molecular neuroscience. This short course includes electrophysiology, and other fundamental techniques. Laboratory exercises run in January and are supplemented by informal lectures. Enrollment requires instructor permission and is limited to 24 graduate students. Prerequisite: NEUR2030. S/NC course
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: NEUR 2030.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.

title: Foundations of Management and Leadership
description: Students will develop a comprehensive understanding of key management and leadership theories that leaders use to effectively design and executive corporate and competitive strategies within organizations. Drawing upon key organizational, management, and strategy concepts and frameworks students will gain an advanced understanding of the skills top leaders need to understand the competitive environment, formulate effective strategies, cascade them inside organizations, manage corporate performance and lead from the upper echelon. Skills will be developed that can be applied across various industry contexts. Starting with vision setting and ending with sustainable success, students will learn tools creating winning strategies and delivering measurable results.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Management (MIM) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.

title: Leadership Ethics & Professional Integrity
description: Students will examine the philosophical underpinnings of leadership ethics and evaluate the ethical theories that comprise modern thinking on the topic. They will also explore the requirements of responsibilities that leaders who are members of professional organizations must adhere to. Through reflection, learners will examine their own moral and ethical values and consider how their own frames of reference impact the choices they make and how those choices will ultimately influence stakeholders and affect society. Students will also develop their own, bespoke personal code of ethics. Through case analysis, reflection, and dialogue, students will refine their thinking regarding how to build trust, lead with integrity and foster ethical cultures. Emphasis is placed on navigating gray areas, upholding accountability, and leading with authenticity in diverse professional contexts.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Management (MIM) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.
