title: Decolonization of Museums: Nations, Museums, Anti Colonialism and the Contemporary Moment
description: Museums are spaces of collection and representation. They are also keepers of knowledge. Museum collections and knowledge are constructed through distinctive power relations. There are of course different kinds of museums but the ethnographic museum has been one center piece of colonial collections. This course will examine how the collections of many museums were established. After this historical collection working through an genealogical method the course will then pay attention to the contemporary debates and practices of various attempts to decolonize various museums. In this regard we will pay attention to four museums: the Tropen Museum in Amsterdam; the British museum, Boston Museum of Fine Arts and to the National Art Gallery of South Africa.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12, 13, GM or GP.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Basic Physics A
description: Survey of mechanics for concentrators in sciences other than physics-including premedical and life science students. Students with more advanced math training are advised to take PHYS 0050, which covers the same topics in physics. Lectures and laboratory. Six hours of attendance.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Basic Physics B
description: Survey of electricity, magnetism, optics, and modern physics for concentrators in sciences other than physics-including premedical students or students without prior exposure to physics who require a less rigorous course than PHYS 0050, 0060. Lectures, conferences, and laboratory.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Basic Physics B
description: Survey of electricity, magnetism, optics, and modern physics for concentrators in sciences other than physics-including premedical students or students without prior exposure to physics who require a less rigorous course than PHYS 0050, 0060. Lectures, conferences, and laboratory.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Foundations of Electromagnetism and Modern Physics
description: An introduction to the principles and phenomena of electricity, magnetism, optics, and the concepts of modern physics. Recommended for those who wish to limit their college physics to two semesters but seek a firm grounding in the subject, including but not limited to those with some previous knowledge of physics. Lectures, conferences, and laboratory. Six hours of attendance. Prerequisite: PHYS 0050. Recommended: MATH 0100.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 0050 or 0070.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Relativity, Waves and Quantum Physics
description: A mathematically rigorous introduction to special relativity and quantum mechanics. The second course in the three-semester sequence (PHYS 0470 being the third) for those seeking the strongest foundation in physics. Also suitable for students better served by an introduction to modern physics rather than electromagnetism. Lectures, conferences, and laboratory. Six hours of attendance. Prerequisite: PHYS 0070 or 0050. Recommended: MATH 0180 or 0200. S/NC
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 0050 or 0070.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Astronomy
description: An introduction to basic ideas and observations in astronomy, starting with the observed sky, coordinates and astronomical calendars and cycles, the historical development of our understanding of astronomical objects. Particular emphasis is placed on the properties of stars, galaxies, and the Universe as a whole, including the basic ideas of cosmology. The material is covered at a more basic level than PHYS 0270. Knowledge of basic algebra and trigonometry is required, but no experience with calculus is necessary. The course includes evening laboratory sessions.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Classical Mechanics
description: Dynamics of particles, rigid bodies, and elastic continua. Normal modes. Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations. Prerequisites: PHYS 0070, 0160 or 0050, 0060 and MATH 0180 or 0200; or approved equivalents.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ((PHYS 0070 or 0050) and (PHYS 0060, 0160 or 0080) and (MATH 0180, 0350 or 0200)).Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Experiments in Modern Physics
description: Introduction to experimental physics. Students perform fundamental experiments in modern quantum physics, including atomic physics, nuclear and particle physics, and condensed matter physics. Visits to research labs at Brown acquaint students with fields of current research. Emphasizes laboratory techniques, statistics, and data analysis. Three lecture/discussion hours and three laboratory hours each week. Required of all physics concentrators. Prerequisites: PHYS 0070, 0160 or 0050, 0060; 0470.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ((PHYS 0070 or 0050) and (PHYS 0160, 0080 or 0060) and PHYS 0470).Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: General Relativity
description: An introduction to Einstein's theory of gravity, including special relativity, spacetime curvature, cosmology and black holes. Prerequisites: PHYS 0500 and MATH 0520 or MATH 0540 or equivalent, or permission of the instructor. Recommended: PHYS 0720. Offered every other year.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 0500 and (MATH 0520 or 0540) or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Nuclear and High Energy Physics
description: A study of modern nuclear and particle physics, with emphasis on the theory and interpretation of experimental results. Prerequisites: PHYS 1410, 1420 (may be taken concurrently), or instructor permission.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 1410, 1420* or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.* May be taken concurrently.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Stellar Structure and the Interstellar Medium
description: This class is an introduction to the physics of stars and their environment. The course covers the fundamental physics that set the physical properties of stars, such as their luminosity, size, spectral properties and how these quantities evolve with time. In addition, it includes a study of the physics that takes place in the gaseous environment surrounding stars, the InterStellar Medium (ISM). The ISM is very important because it contains a wealth of information on the evolutionary history of galaxies, their composition, formation and future. Prerequisites: PHYS 0270, PHYS 0470, or instructor permission. PHYS 1530 (perhaps taken concurrently) is strongly recommended but not required.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 0270 and 0470 and (MATH 0190, 0100, 0170, 0200, 0180 or 0350) or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Quantum Mechanics B
description: See Quantum Mechanics A, (PHYS 1410) for course description.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 1410 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Modern Physics Laboratory
description: A sequence of intensive, advanced experiments often introducing sophisticated techniques. Prerequisites: PHYS 0470, 0500 and 0560; and MATH 0520, 0540 or PHYS 0720; or approved equivalents.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: (PHYS 0470, 0500 and 0560) and (MATH 0520, 0540 or PHYS 0720) or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Semiconductor Devices
description: An introduction to semiconductor device physics and basic electronic properties of semiconductors, including junctions, heterojunction, and fundamental device building blocks. Current and proposed semiconductor devices: field effect transistors, bipolar transistors, quantum-effect devices, and optoelectronic devices. A brief fabrication lab will introduce junction fabrication in the cleanroom. Advanced topics, such as heterojunction bipolar transistors and silicon-on-insulator FETs, are included in the graduate version.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ENGN 0510, PHYS 0470 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Laser and Nonlinear Optics
description: This is a second course on optics and photonics, intended for juniors (and beyond) interested in more advanced topics in modern optics who have already completed ENGN1690 (or equivalent). Topics to be covered include some topics in linear optics (Fourier optics, coherence) and lasers (fundamentals of laser operation, gain and gain saturation, resonators, transient laser phenomena). We will then discuss light-matter interactions in the nonlinear regime, relying on a classical or semi-classical treatment. Topics will include frequency conversion via mixing or parametric processes, and degenerate third-order self-induced effects. Time permitting, we will discuss some of the most recent breakthroughs in optically-driven nonlinear processes such as the generation of attosecond pulses (physics Nobel Prize 2023).
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Computational Physics
description: This course provides students with an introduction to scientific computation, primarily as applied to physical science problems. It will assume a basic knowledge of programming and will focus on how computational methods can be used to study physical systems complementing experimental and theoretical techniques. Prerequisites: PHYS 0070, 0160 (or 0050, 0060) and 0470 (or ENGN 0510); MATH 0180 or 0200 or 0350; the ability to write a simple computer program in Fortran, Matlab, C or C++.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: ((PHYS 0070 or 0050) and (PHYS 0160, 0080 or 0060) and (PHYS 0470 or ENGN 0510) and (MATH 0180, 0200 or 0350)) or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Soft Matter
description: This course provides an introduction to soft matter: polymers, elastomers, liquid crystals, and colloids. Students in physics, engineering, chemistry and applied mathematics may find this course useful. Familiarity with classical statistical mechanics (PHYS1530) is required. We will use scaling arguments and simple physical pictures as much as possible.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Quantum Information
description: Quantum information is the modern study of how to encode and transmit information on the quantum scale in many ways fundamentally diﬀerent from classical information. This course will connect a standard treatment of Quantum mechanics with information theory. The first part of the course will focus on the quantum gates and universal sets, and how it is used for quantum computation. Then the question of measurements and control of quantum states in order to perform quantum computation will be addressed. The actual problems and limitations will be discussed and an introduction to quantum error correction will be given. To finish the course, the subject of quantum sensing will be introduced and its link with quantum information.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PHYS 1410 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

description: This graduate course in general relativity and cosmology will cover the principles of Einstein's general theory of relativity, differential geometry, the first order formulation of general relativity (Einstein-Cartan theory), experimental tests of general relativity and black holes. The second half of the course will focus on relativistic cosmology with a focus on its interface with field theory.

description: The goal of the course is to explain the effects of interactions between the electrons on the properties of quantum materials. In particular, upon completing the course you will acquire deep understanding of the physics of conductors, symmetry broken phases and strongly interacting topological phases such as Hall effect. We will particularly concentrate on the phenomenology of these systems.

title: Health and Healing through the Lens of Culture
description: Through the lenses of culture, we examine health and healing in the US public health and health care systems and in select countries around the world. Course work includes reading and discussing essays in the book, Healing by Heart: Clinical and Ethical Case Studies of Hmong Families and Western Providers; journal articles, watching videos; interviewing physicians working in cross-cultural settings; and writing brief reflective essays on class material and discussions. Two papers (5 page and 10 page) will be required for the class. Students will learn how to use the library's resources, how to properly reference papers, and basic presentation skills. This course will preferentially enroll PLME students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01, 02, 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introductory Polish
description: This course is a continuation of PLSH 0100 or the equivalent, and it aims to establish essential "survival skills" that are needed in real-life situations. The primary focus is building vocabulary, reading, and engaging in guided conversation. In addition to learning the language, students are introduced to Polish literature and culture through film, music, and video presentations.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Polish
description: This course is designed for students who want to continue exploring Polish language and culture and have completed the Introductory Polish language sequence (PLSH 0150/0100, 0200 and 0300) or have otherwise acquired basic proficiency required for the second year sequence. The main goal of the course is to enhance students' Polish language skills (speaking, writing, reading and listening) through authentic participation in Polish culture: film, politics, and poetry. The course incorporates various Internet resources, selected contemporary Polish films as well as up-to-date news from Poland. Discussed topics and level of difficulty will be determined by students' individual interests and needs.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: (PLSH 0100 or 0150) and PLSH 0200 and 0300.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Polish
description: In this course students will further develop their skills in speaking, reading, writing and understanding Polish. They will continue developing reading and writing skills by reading increasingly more elaborate authentic texts, writing essays, and learning about Polish stylistics, syntax, and grammar at the advanced level. Their listening skills will be cultivated by in-class interactions and listening to authentic Polish audio and video recordings. Emphasis in this course will be on mastering oral expression and vocabulary building, as well as comprehension of fiction and non-fiction texts of a moderate level of difficulty. The course will be conducted almost exclusively in Polish.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: (PLSH 0100 or 0150) and PLSH 0200, 0300, 0400 and 0500.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Accelerated Portuguese
description: This course serves as an accelerated introduction to Portuguese, one of the most widely spoken languages in the world. It is also an introduction to the diverse cultures of Portuguese-speaking societies. Specifically, the course will look into the ethnic, racial, social, and gender diversity in these cultures. Designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Portuguese, POBS 0105 meets five hours per week.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Writing and Speaking Portuguese
description: Designed to improve the students' ability in contemporary spoken and written Portuguese. Using such cultural items as short stories, plays, films, videos, newspaper and magazine articles, and popular music, students discuss a variety of topics with the aim of developing good communication skills. Attention also given to developing writing ability. A systematic review of Portuguese grammar is included. Prerequisite: POBS 0105, or POBS 0110, or placement. Conducted in Portuguese. Completion of POBS 0400 is the minimum requirement for participation in the Brown-in-Brazil Program. Offered every semester.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Women, Arts & Imagination in the Portuguese-Speaking World
description: This course explores how women from across the Portuguese-speaking world have used art, literature, music, and film to tell their own stories and reimagine history. From the revolutionary poems of Angola and Mozambique to the songs of Cape Verde and the novels of Brazil and Portugal, we will discover how creative voices challenge silence, question power, and offer new ways of seeing identity, belonging, and memory. Through readings, films, and creative activities, students will examine how women artists transform personal experience into collective expression and how art becomes a space for rewriting the past and imagining new futures. Conducted in Portuguese.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: POBS 0105 and 0400.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Performing Brazil: Language, Theater, Culture
description: Designed to deepen the students' understanding of Brazilian culture and society through the performing arts. Students will read a series of plays and respond to them in a variety of ways: in writing, verbally, and through performance. The course will include poetry and music as these can also be performed. Throughout the semester students will also be working on creating their own performance pieces. Conducted in Portuguese.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Portugal: The Journey from "Welcoming" Policies to Anti-Immigration Mobilization
description: The course examines the shift in Portugal's migration landscape, from a colonial legacy of openness to cultural diversity to the rise of anti-immigration movements. It explores how Portugal's national myth of a country open to diversity, shaped by its colonial past, obscures issues of racism and migration. The course traces how migration policies have evolved in a postcolonial context, analyzes media's role in perpetuating stereotypes, and investigates the rise of far-right anti-immigration mobilization. It also highlights immigrant resistance to these changes. Using Paulo Freire's critical pedagogy, the course encourages collaborative learning and participatory practices, fostering dialogue and decolonizing methodologies in migration studies. Students will engage actively in discussions, readings, and reflections, contributing to an exchange of ideas among students, faculty, and guest lecturers. Taught in English, course instructor: visiting FLAD professor, Thais França
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Modern and Contemporary Brazilian Poetry
description: An intensive reading of selected Brazilian poets of the past eighty years, including Carlos Drummond de Andrade, João Cabral de Melo Neto, Mário Faustino, Paulo Leminski, Ana Cristina Cesar, the "concretistas", and Salgado Maranhão. Each student will be responsible for an oral presentation about an additional poet, to be chosen in consultation with the instructor. Conducted in Portuguese.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Political Thought
description: What is justice? What is freedom? What is the basis of political authority? What is the nature of the best regime? Why should we obey the laws? When may we legitimately resist? These and other perennial questions of political life are explored. Readings includes Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, and J.S. Mill.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: Introduces students to the sub-field of comparative politics or politics within states. Topics include types of regimes (i.e., democratic, authoritarian-with-adjectives, totalitarian); transitions to democracy; collapse of democratic regimes; democratizing, revolutionary and ethnic challenges to the state; and globalization. The course also pays attention to modes of analysis in comparative politics. Cases will be drawn from various regions, including Western and Eastern Europe, Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and Latin America.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Politics of Race and the Criminal Justice System
description: This course examines the politics of race and the criminal justice system in the U.S. It proceeds in three parts. First, it examines the political origins and consequences of racial disparities in citizens' interactions with the police, courts and prisons. Next, it considers how the public, the media, and politicians relate and respond to these issues. Finally, the course concludes by examining the prospects for reform and the consequences of inaction.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 01 or 02.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Politics, Ethics, and Art of Corruption
description: What explains variation in corruption across and within democratic countries? What motivates the citizens and officials who engage in corrupt acts? Is there such a thing as a "culture of corruption"? In order to understand these questions (and attempt to answer them), this course takes a somewhat unconventional approach. While we use the analytical approach of the social sciences as our foundation, we also draw on films (documentary and fiction), interviews, and journalistic reporting to understand the individual and systemic causes and consequences of corruption, as well as the narratives citizens create surrounding corruption. Some weeks we focus on a particular country, while in other weeks we take a thematic approach. Throughout the course, we will draw on examples from across the globe, including Latin America, Africa, Europe, and Asia.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03 or 04.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Topics in American Constitutional Law
description: This course will examine major constitutional controversies within the context of wider debates in political and legal theory. Readings from Supreme Court cases and prominent texts in political/legal theory. Each year we will focus on a different theme and set of constitutional issues. Topics might include a mix of federalism, separation of powers, privacy, free speech, and abortion. We will also focus how political and legal theory helps us to consider these topics in tandem .
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: U.S. Congress
description: The Founders established the U.S. Congress in Article I of the Constitution. It created that body as guardian of the nation's purse strings and empowered it to "make all laws necessary and proper." Will examine the Congress's structure, rules and procedures, traditions, precedents, campaigns, elections, parties, budget process, Member's constituencies and role in the system of checks and balances with the president and the courts. The impact of procedure on policy outcomes and the impacts of the 2020 election on the House and Senate will be explored. The course will consistently relate the characteristics and history of Congress to current events.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Public Opinion and American Democracy
description: Public opinion is an essential component of democracy. Considering the lack of familiarity about current events, how does public opinion affect public policy? Perhaps more importantly, should it? To assess these questions, we will explore how to measure public opinion and what polls tell us. We will then assess the roots of public opinion and analyze the public policy and representational impact of people's preferences.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Constitutional Law: Governmental Powers
description: This course examines governmental powers under the United States Constitution, addressing the powers of Congress, the President, and the courts, as well as the relationship between the national and state governments. The primary reading materials will be leading Supreme Court cases, supplemented by additional reading materials on history and legal theory. The course will consider the role of the courts in enforcing constitutional principles in a democratic system, as well as theories of constitutional interpretation and constitutional change.
registration_restrictions: Students with a semester level of 01 or 02 may not enroll.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Politics, Markets and States in Developing Countries
description: How can we explain fundamental differences in economic performance and policy across developing countries in the face of Globalization? Why are some countries praised as economic "miracles," yet others seem mired in inescapable stagnation? This course addresses these questions by introducing the basic topics, concepts, and theoretical approaches that comprise the field of political economy of development. The course draws on case studies from Asia, Africa, and Latin America.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Capitalism, Democracy, and Geopolitics in Europe
description: As the home of parliamentary democracy in the era of mass politics, Europe is today contending with the new challenges of twenty-first century politics. This course begins by examining how different versions of capitalism and the welfare state emerged in Europe. It then asks which new forces reinforce and which undermine democratic politics in Europe today. Topics include immigration, religious diversity, technology competition, military conflict on Europe's perimeter, and underlying changes in European geopolitics.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Politics of Health and Disease
description: Despite remarkable advances in medical research and treatments during the twentieth century, we continue to confront grave challenges from infectious diseases. In addition to their human toll, infectious diseases can exact enormous economic costs, threaten social stability and, trigger political crises. Why are some more effective at countering the same infectious disease? Why have disease-controlling technologies met with such divergent responses? Why has the same state been relatively successful in countering certain diseases but has struggled with others? This course will pose and seek to advance our collective understanding of these critical questions about the politics of health and disease.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: African American Politics
description: Focuses on the contemporary African American politics in various spheres of the American political environment. Examines also how the concept of an African American community has evolved and shifted historically. We will pay particular attention to the growing diversity within the African American community and discuss what these changes mean for black political participation, representation, and organizing.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: 21st Century Social Movements
description: In this course, we explore theoretical and empirical research on social movements, defined as collective mobilizations that are either large scale or remain organized for at least one year, & aim to instigate political change. During the semester we examine and debate a range of scholarship, both theoretical and case-based, across the disciplines of political science, sociology, psychology and other relevant fields that address the dynamics of radical imagination, movement emergence, the process of organizing, the process of professionalization, the process of demobilization/abeyance, and the phenomenon of political acceptance. We also endeavor to assess the different political impacts social movements make in politics and policy in the United States and beyond.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Politics of Climate Change
description: Climate change is arguably the most important global challenge in the 21st century. It will reshape weather patterns, storms, sea levels, and agricultural output worldwide. Mitigating climate change will require massive economic transformations, affecting energy, transportation, and industrial sectors. What are the politics of that transformation? What are the political forces obstructing it? How do social movements, institutions, and economic interests interact to shape the national and global response to climate change? This course offers answers and insights, primarily from the perspective of political science. It also draws on knowledge from other disciplines.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: International Political Economy
description: An introduction to the politics of international economic relations. Examines the history of international political economy and theoretical approaches to understanding it. Also analyzes several key contemporary issues in international institutions such as the International Monetary Fund and World Trade Organization, globalization and its consequences, and challenges in foreign economic policy-making.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Political Research Methods
description: Introduction to quantitative research methods in political science. Topics include research design, descriptive statistics, statistical hypothesis testing, and bivariate and multivariate regression. By the end of the course, students will have the requisite skills to intelligently consume and produce basic quantitative social science research. Enrollment limited to 24 sophomore, junior, and senior Political Science, International Relations, or Public Policy concentrators.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the International Relations (AB), Political Science (AB) or Public Policy (AB) programs.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Political Journalism
description: Exploration of the development of political reporting and analysis of contemporary public affairs reporting. Will address key elements of the best political journalism, as well as the manner in which political journalism affects public opinion, political attitudes, and campaigns and elections. Enrollment limited to 20 junior and senior Political Science concentrators.
registration_restrictions: Students with a semester level of 01, 02, 03 or 04 may not enroll.Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AB) program.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Democracy and Inequality in American Cities
description: Explores the relationship between democracy and inequality in contemporary American cities. The seminar considers different kinds of inequality - economic, political and group/horizontal – from the standpoint of national politics in the United States. The focus then shifts to the literature on urban politics in the United States, assessing the major contrasting theoretical perspectives on the causes of local inequalities in American cities. Finally, we focus on unequal access to public safety and justice. Over the course of the semester, students will be expected to carry out "fieldwork" involving first-hand observation of local inequalities in the Greater Providence area.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Urban Politics and Policy
description: In this course, students examine the politics of urban America, and the causes and consequences of urban poverty and inequality. Enrollment limited to 20.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Political Communication
description: This course will focus on the importance of written and oral communication in public decision-making, particularly in the Congressional context. The course will examine the impact on political interactions, and the influencing of public policy decisions and outcomes. The course will emphasize some of the practical tools for producing relevant, useful material in the professional policy and the political communications arenas. The course requires several writing assignments focusing on different public policy analyses and political communications tools as well as active class participation including oral presentations.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Political Development of Taiwan
description: With growing risk of superpower conflict in the Taiwan Straits, Taiwan – home today to 23.4 million people – has become a major focus for global attention. This seminar is premised on three ideas – that to understand Taiwan, one must go beyond the geopolitical, and instead delve deeply into Taiwan's multi-century political evolution; that doing so will offer insights into some of the most significant macro-political phenomena in human history (e.g., settler colonialism, imperialism, authoritarianism, democratization, etc.); and, that doing so will also offer greater understanding of, and a wider range of potential solutions for, contemporary geopolitical concerns. Topics include Taiwan under Dutch rule, Taiwan as part of the Qing Empire, Taiwan's socio-political evolution under Japanese colonial rule, the building of the KMT state on Taiwan, authoritarianism and the "White Terror," Taiwan's democratization, and post-democratization identity formation.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Ancients and Moderns: Quarrels and Continuities
description: Examines the political thought of Plato and Aristotle together with three modern thinkers whose work was especially animated by engagement with their views of politics: Hobbes, Rousseau, and Nietzsche. Topics include the ends of politics and the nature of good government; the meaning of justice; the relationship between public and private; the value of equality and of hierarchy; the nature and role of freedom; the place of virtue in political life; and the relationship between philosophy and politics. In reading these moderns through the lens of Plato and Aristotle, we gain a richer understanding of both the quarrels and the continuities between ancient and modern political thought – and the dynamic relationship between them.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Senior Honors Thesis Preparation
description: This course is a continuation of POLS 1910. Political Science Honors students who are completing their theses should enroll. Prerequisite: POLS 1910. Instructor permission required.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: POLS 1910 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Enrollment limited to students with a semester level of 07, 08, 09, 10, 11, 12 or 13.Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AB) program.Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Political Behavior
description: This seminar is designed for Political Science PhD students. It will serve as an introduction to the vast literature surrounding public opinion and mass political behavior. The topics that we will cover in the class include public opinion, vote choice, political participation, and elite political behavior, among other things. The assigned readings for this class include literature from both the American politics and Comparative politics subfields.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Institutions, Crime, and Violence
description: Will examine relationships and interactions among institutions, criminal actors, and violence. State-based institutions play an important role in explaining the level of disorganized or organized crime. Organized crime groups, in turn, influence both state-based institutions (for example, through corrupting officials) and other criminal activity, often by creating the "rules of the game" by which other criminals can act. Finally, both state-based and criminal actors and institutions influence the level of violence in society. Each of these three influences, and is influenced by, the others. This course offers the opportunity to better understand how these three factors relate to each other.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (PHD) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: American Public Policy
description: This graduate seminar surveys the literature on the politics of public policy. While the primary focus is the contemporary US policy state, the course also examines American policymaking in cross-national perspective. Policymaking is a complex process in which outcomes are shaped by the interplay of interests, ideas, and institutions. To understand these outcomes, the course draws on theories of policymaking, public administration, public law, and institutionalism as frameworks of analysis. Substantive topics include the US welfare state, legislative politics, federalism, the influence of racial politics in policymaking, policy feedback, the consequences of partisan polarization for governance, and government as a problem-solving institution.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Preparing the Prospectus II
description: This course covers selected topics in research design and methodology and is designed to help students enrolled in the Political Science PhD program to write and defend a prospectus in their third year of study. Prerequisite: POLS 2050.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: POLS 2050.Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Becoming a Political Scientist: Professionalization and Strategies for Thriving
description: This full-year course (half-credit each semester) is designed for 3rd year PhD students in Political Science and covers a range of topics that are crucial to students as they transition from the course phase to the research phase of their careers. Topics include practical and substantive issues related to planning and carrying out research, collaborating with others, teaching, ethics, obtaining external funding, and providing feedback to other scholars. Course only open to Political Science PhD students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: International Political Economy
description: Graduate seminar that surveys the subfield of international political economy. Outlines the historical development of the subfield as it moved from questions of US decline to issues of international cooperation and compliance and back to issues of US decline. Places the US research agenda in comparison with schools of IPE in the rest of the world. Topics covered include globalization and distribution, development, IGOs and NGOs in the IPE, Public and Private Authority, the rise and fall of nations. Open to POLS PhD graduate students only.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (PHD) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The International Political Economy of Global Finance
description: This class gives graduate students a thorough grounding in the Architecture and Plumbing of Global finance. The Architecture is the foundations of money and the institutions and policies that manage it. This includes the production of money, Central Bank and Treasury basics, Bond Markets, Balance of Payments, Public and Private Markets and currency hierarchies. The second half of the course deals with the plumbing, which is how politics influences money in the real world. This includes issues of financial governance, financial sanctions, inflation and the offshore financial system. Although finance is now more prominent in IPE research it remains at the frontier of research topics in mainstream IPE. As such, it is an excellent area to conduct research since it remains, to steal a line from one of the field's pioneers, Susan Strange, an 'open range' of inquiry.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Authoritarian Politics
description: This graduate seminar examines contemporary scholarship on authoritarian politics. The course seeks to familiarize students with salient theoretical perspectives and debates, with an eye toward assisting students in conducting original research. Course topics include elite politics, coups and leadership challenges, revolutions, power sharing institutions, repression, propaganda, and censorship. Course readings focus on recently published book manuscripts, which include a range of qualitative, quantitative, and experimental methods. Many of the readings center on authoritarian regimes in Asia, particularly modern China.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Proseminar in Political Theory II
description: Examines the political thought of Plato and Aristotle together with three modern thinkers whose work was especially influenced (or animated) by engagement with these ancient views of politics: Machiavelli, Rousseau, and Nietzsche. In exploring these moderns in particular, we also get a view of early modern, high modern, and postmodern receptions of the ancients. Enrollment limited to 14. Open to graduate students.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Black Political Thought
description: Black thinkers have made important yet often unrecognized contributions to political theory and philosophy. This course examines the history of black political thought, focusing on the answers black thinkers have formulated to key questions in political theory, such as: What is justice? What is freedom? What are the conditions of possibility for democracy? How should we theorize race? What is racial justice? More than other intellectual traditions, black political thought has been centrally concerned with racism and inequality, but also black refusal and black life. We will pay special attention to the distinctive concepts and modes of theorizing developed by black thinkers, particularly how they conceive the relationship between race, class, gender, sexuality, etc. Rather than providing an overview of black political thought in all times and places, the course will focus on close readings of a few key thinkers.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Qualitative and Mixed Methods Research
description: This graduate seminar offers an introduction to the design and implementation of social science research that deploys qualitative data and analysis in conjunction with other methods of inquiry. We explore the set of tools that is conventionally considered to comprise qualitative methods, including case studies, small-N comparisons, process tracing, sequential analysis, interviews and participant observation. Starting from the premise that each research method has its strengths and weaknesses, we also consider how qualitative methods can be combined productively with other methods of inquiry, including "large-N" quantitative analysis, experiments, spatial/geographic analysis, and multilevel analysis spanning different scales.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Quantitative Research Methods II
description: An intermediate statistics course for graduate students. Topics include multiple regression, statistical inference, categorical dependent variable models, instrumental variable models, and an introduction to time series. Course readings and applications examine models used in different fields of political science and public policy including American institutions, comparative politics, and international relations. Open to graduate students concentrating in Political Science or Public Policy.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM), Political Science (PHD), Public Affairs (MPA) or Public Policy (MPP) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Quantitative Research Methods IV
description: Quantitative Research Methods IV is an advanced graduate seminar on the design, implementation, analysis, and interpretation of experiments in social science and policy. The course provides in-depth training in laboratory, survey, and field experiments, with strong emphasis on real-world policy applications. Students learn core principles of causal inference, experimental design, treatment implementation, power analysis, pre-registration, and threats to validity. Through lectures and critical discussion of cutting-edge experimental research in social science and policy, students develop the tools to design their own experiments and to rigorously evaluate experimental evidence for both academic and policy research.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment limited to students in the Political Science (AM) or Political Science (PHD) programs.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Basic Persian
description:
Fast-paced course for beginners. Course stresses acquisition of Persian alphabet and basic grammatical patterns, beginning levels of speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Strong emphasis on the links between language and culture.
This is the second half of a year-long course. Students must have taken PRSN 0100 to receive credit for this course. If PRSN 0100 was taken for credit then this course must be taken for credit; if taken as an audit, this course must also be taken as an audit. Exceptions to this policy must be approved by both the academic department and the Committee on Academic Standing.
One additional hour in consultation with instructor and enrolled students.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: PRSN 0100.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Persian Language and Culture
description: Expands students' proficiency in modern Persian language and culture; develops listening, speaking, reading and writing skills at the intermediate level through various texts and multimedia. Prerequisite: PRSN 0300. One additional hour in consultation with instructor and enrolled students.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PRSN 0300 or 0105.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Mixed Methods Evaluation Research
description: This applied methods course introduces students to the design and practice of program evaluation in real-world policy settings. Working in partnership with the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services (DYS), students will develop and apply mixed-methods evaluation tools to understand a core question: why youth elect not to participate in DYS's transition support program, and how youth transition outcomes are conditioned by individual and community resilience. Through an integration of conceptual foundations and hands-on application, the course emphasizes the use of logic models, data collection instruments, and analytic approaches that produce actionable, evidence-based insights for policy and program improvement.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Applications in Geographic Information Systems
description: This course is for graduate students seeking to develop their GIS skills further and to gain practice applying GIS methods in a research-oriented setting. The course is organized around a set of social science topics—as opposed to sequential coverage of various methods—and the focus is on getting from research question to analytical results to interpretation of findings. The course emphasizes practice matching concept to tool, as well as identifying appropriate tools and combining them successfully. Independent research skills using GIS are developed via the reading of published literature, the guided replication of results, and the interpretation of findings.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: PSTC 2612 or 1340.Enrollment limited to students in the Social Analysis and Research (SCB) program.Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Happiness and the Pursuit of the Good Life
description: What is happiness, and how does it relate to the "good life," or a life well-lived? This is an age-old question, and in this course we will investigate religious and philosophical answers alongside insights drawn from modern positive psychology. A major goal of the course is to give you intellectual tools that will help you to construct a meaningful life. Areas of study will include value determination; gratitude; status and wealth; and mindfulness.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Religious Lives of Everyday People
description: For centuries, scholars have looked to religious institutions, theological doctrines, and sacred texts to explain religion's form and function in culture and society. And while this approach has enabled scholars to neatly prescribe what counts as religious, it's also caused them to ignore the ways people's daily faith practices make a mess of this work. Drawing on sub-fields in religious studies, anthropology, and sociology, this course explores how formal ideas of religion expand when confronted with the normality of everyday life. From cooking and talking to prayer and devotion, the "religious" and "non-religious" things people do tell us a lot about how religion animates and is animated by lived experience, and how porous the boundary is between the "sacred" and "profane".
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Jesus
description: Who was, and is, Jesus? Who decides? What can we know about the historical Jesus and who he became? In this course, we will begin with the earliest accounts of Jesus as recounted in the canonical gospels and outside it (e.g., the Gospel of Judas). Then we will turn to the many ways that later generations of Christians (both heretical and orthodox) and non-Christians depicted Jesus. We will read canonical and non-canonical Christian texts, Jewish accounts of Jesus, and attend to differences as Christianity spread both westward toward Ireland and eastward through the Silk Road toward China.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Sacred Bodies
description: How did ancient Christians understand embodied holiness? What did the bodies of saints demonstrate or reveal? Different notions of what makes a body "sacred" have abounded in Christian history, and continue to inflect our broad cultural thinking about gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, and health. This course will explore those constructions and their malleability through the reading of ancient Christian hagiography (stories about saints). We will ask whether and how multiple notions of sacred bodies might be visible in Christian imagination. The course is organized around three broad categories of holy bodies: the heroic body, the desiring body, and the performing body. Seminar format. WRIT
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Both Divine and Deficient: Women between Discourse and Practice in East Asian Religious Traditions
description: In this course, we will examine the main religious traditions of East Asia—— Confucianism, Buddhism, Daoism, Shintoism, and folk practices like Shamanism—— through the lens of gender. These traditions offer diverse narratives, discourses, and prescriptions, which shaped and informed women's religious lives. In some cases, female practitioners are treated positively, while in others, we find more disparaging depictions. As we examine the treatment of female practitioners within these traditions, we will also observe how specific historical women navigated gender expectations, created their own spaces of practice, and offered their own interpretations. The geographical breadth of the course, which includes China, Japan, and Korea, will allow us to consider historical continuities and departures between these different regions. Finally, we will also deliberate on the ways these traditions can confront and address modern issues related to women and gender.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Spirit Writing and Popular Religion in China
description: What does it mean to receive a message from a god? How have ordinary people in Chinese history used writing not just to record the divine—but to produce it? This seminar explores spirit writing (fuji 扶乩), a ritual practice of communicating with gods, ghosts, and immortals through writing, and the broader world of Chinese popular religion from which it emerged. Through case studies of mountain cults, female immortals, child mediums, and moral texts, we will examine how people across Chinese history sought divine insight, legitimacy, and healing. Readings include miracle tales, ritual manuals, and planchette transcripts, alongside scholarship from anthropology, history, and religious studies. Students will gain new perspectives on the creative, contested, and often gendered process of engaging with the spirit world.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Indian Cinema and Social Change
description: How does film imagine a changing nation? This course explores India's vibrant cinematic landscape in the 21st century, from Bollywood blockbusters to boundary-pushing independent films, that grapple with love, desire, gender, caste, religion, corruption, and activism. We'll ask how filmmakers turn the camera into an instrument of social critique and emotional transformation. How do sound, color, and image shape awareness, empathy, and revolt? Through close viewing, discussion, and creative analysis, students will engage the politics and poetics of India's visual storytelling in a time of rapid globalization and cultural flux. Tracing cinema's evolution from postcolonial roots to its digital, transnational reach today, the course invites you to see how contemporary films both mirror and challenge the realities of modern India—and how they ask audiences everywhere to feel, question, and reimagine the world anew.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Psychedelics in Religion, Science, and Healing
description: Psychedelics are in the midst of a renaissance of public attention. Though used for millennia in indigenous ceremonies and religious rites, it is only in the last century that they have played a role in Western science, medicine, and culture. Literally "manifesting the soul," psychedelics have been both stigmatized and hyped, remaining illegal or controversial in many contemporary contexts even as they are marketed as the "next big thing" in mental health care. This course compares and contrasts the cultural and ontological contexts for psychedelic use from indigenous and religious ceremonies to contemporary scientific clinical trials and neuroscience. Along the way, pressing questions within the psychedelic field will be investigated from an interdisciplinary lens and with an appreciation for history and context.

title: Religious Freedom in America
description: This course examines the ideal of religious freedom, which often is seen a cornerstone of American society. Interrogating that view, students explore the idea and practice of religious freedom in the past and present, paying close attention to its limitations, contradictions, and ironies. Although the course draws especially upon studies of religion, law, and politics in the United States, students also consider forms of religion and secularism from around the world. Reading-intensive and discussion-driven, this course has no prerequisites.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Undergraduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Ecotheology in Ancient Christianity
description: How did early Christians understand the relationship of humanity to the natural world, the animal kingdom, and the created order? What were the obligations and responsibilities of Christians regarding care for the world? How did they manifest a relationship to God? A study of the ancient Christian conception of humanity's place in the cosmos, as lived out in the daily life of the Christians in the Roman Empire. The course will focus on the first seven Christian centuries, with attention to how legalization and ascendancy reshaped Christian ideas on these matters. Seminar.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Critiques of Religion + Capitalism
description: This interdisciplinary and comparative seminar analyzes the economic aspects of religion and the religious aspects of capitalism. It takes up these questions in relation to historical and contemporary archives, and it prioritizes feminist, critical race, and queer analysis. Readings and course themes press boundaries of how we might think about religion and reveal new directions for an analysis and critique of capitalism. We will ask questions like the following: How can we trace the growth of the idea that participation in global free markets can facilitate relations of justice? What moral frameworks and theories of human life underwrite the vision of capital markets as a theater for political-ethical action? Under what circumstances can capitalist philosophies and practices be understood in terms of religion?
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Conservative Thought: Religion, Politics, Ethics
description: The conservative movement is ascendant in the United States and elsewhere. Almost four out of ten Americans self-identify as conservative. Whereas much of our political discourse plays out in unruly and truncated terms in social media, talk radio, and partisan journalism, conservatism is a long-standing intellectual tradition with considered perspectives on religion, politics, and ethics. This course aims to come to a greater understanding of these views. We will read texts that have been influential for conservatism, looking at themes such as virtue, tradition, community, religious belonging, natural law, nationalism, and freedom.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Heresy and Orthodoxy in Islamic Thought
description: Orthodoxy is defined as "right belief" while Heresy is just the opposite, but those definitions have always been in tension with society and culture. This course will interrogate theory and history to ask "What are Islamic Orthodoxy and Heresy?" From Islamic Law to who is or is not a "heretic" we will uncover interpretations of religious law, practice, and culture to learn how scholars apply orthodoxy or heresy to disrupt and unsettle notions of what "Islam" was at different moments, and how their interpretations force us to think of new ways to envision the formation of communities.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Problem of Evil
description: What kind of God would preside over a world in which injustice occurs? One of the earliest debates in Islamic history had to do with the question of theodicy: the problem of evil. This was connected to issues of free will and predestination. From the early Middle Ages onward people asked, what kind of all-powerful God holds humans accountable for things out of their power to control? If people are in fact in control of their own actions, what would that say about the nature and power of God? Does evil come from people or God, and if the latter, what does that say about the nature of Divinity? In this course we will discuss these issues and much more from the perspective of Islamic philosophy, ethics, history, politics, and theology from the Middle Ages to the present day.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Take Back Your Mind! Resisting the Attention Economy Through Critical Contemplative Practices
description: The term 'attention economy' refers to the business-marketing system that treats human attention as a commodity, an economic resource with substantial fungibility or exchangeability. This often leads to the loss of attentional autonomy and manipulation for economic and political purposes. As Chris Hayes says in his recent book The Siren's Call: "From inside our own being, attention is what constitutes our very self, but from the perspective of entities outside of us, attention is like gold in a stream, oil in a rock." Asian contemplative practices developed within the Buddhist traditions provide attentional training within a complementary dualistic and nondualistic epistemological framework that offers a firmer foundation than many of the deracinated practices available today. This advanced course will focus on the development of renewed sovereignty over our attention using the full range of distinctive Contemplative Studies pedagogies.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: COST 0100, 0540, UNIV 0540, COST 0125, RELS 0125, COST 0520, RELS 0520, COST 0535, RELS 0535, COST 0555, RELS 0555, COST 0565, RELS 0565, COST 1420, RELS 1420, COST 1441, RELS 1441, EAST 1880C, COST 1082, 1020, UNIV 1000, COST 1030, RELS 1705B, PHP 1880, 1890, COST 1090 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.

title: American Religious Histories
description: This course explores the histories and historiographies of religion in North America, focusing especially the lands that became the United States. By engaging both classic and contemporary approaches to the historical study of religious life, this course not only familiarizes students with persistent scholarly debates and narratives but also helps students understand how and why historians have used particular methods to address varied challenges and objectives. Ultimately, the course will equip students to pursue their own research projects in ways that build creatively and rigorously on existing scholarship.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Digital Religion
description: Given the advent and proliferation of new media technologies, students of religion must explore how religious beliefs, practices, and communities are confronted, impacted, and (re)shaped by digital logics and online spaces. Paying special attention to digital landscapes like social media, mobile apps, streaming, and artificial intelligence, this course explores how people use digital technologies to do religion and the methodological and theoretical stakes of studying and defining this enterprise.
registration_restrictions: Enrollment is limited to Graduate level students.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intensive Russian
description: Intensively-paced introduction to Russian culture and language; completes one year of study in one semester (RUSS 0110 = RUSS 0100-0200). Comprehension and use of contemporary Russian; fundamentals of Russian grammar; vocabulary acquisition; focus on oral communication. Introduces aspects of everyday culture of Russia and the former U.S.S.R. Ten to fifteen hours weekly work outside the classroom. Enrollment limited to 18.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Introductory Russian
description: Introduction to Russian language and culture. Oral and written communication in Russian; emphasis on the culture of Russia and the former U.S.S.R., including the changes that have reshaped everyday life for citizens of Russia. Five meetings per week, plus use of audio, video, and Web materials. Prerequisite: RUSS 0100 or RUSS 0250. Enrollment limited to 18.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: RUSS 0100 or 0250.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Intermediate Russian
description: Continues development of language proficiency while broadening understanding of Russian culture via readings in literature and history. Includes expansion of vocabulary for dealing with conversational topics and review of Russian grammar. Features literary and nonliterary readings in Russian, as well as video and computer resources. Five class meetings per week. Prerequisite: RUSS 0300 or placement by exam. Enrollment limited to 18.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: RUSS 0300.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Advanced Russian
description: Examines selected topics in Russian culture and history as depicted in readings, the media, and Russian and Soviet films. Language work emphasizes increasing facility with spoken Russian and developing writing skills. Includes work on advanced grammar and syntax. Four class meetings per week. Prerequisites: RUSS 0500 or placement. Enrollment limited to 18.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: RUSS 0500.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Special Topics in Russian Studies II: Advanced Reading and Conversation
description: A continuation of Russian 1110. Examines aspects of Russian culture as manifested in Russian literature. Readings range from fairy tales to contemporary works. Extensive classroom discussion and frequent writing assignments. Prerequisite: RUSS 1110, 1700, or written permission. May be repeated once with permission of the instructor. Enrollment limited to 18.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Blackness in Russian Political and Cultural History
description: This course provides a historical, literary, and political survey of Russia's encounters with different ideas of "blackness," from the rise of Abram Gannibal as a prominent black intellectual and statesman during the reign of Emperor Peter the Great, to Russia's response to BLM during President Vladimir Putin's current administration. Drawing on a variety of sources, including novels, biographies, film, media reports, and contemporary scholarly research, the course explores the concepts of race, belonging, otherness, and duality as they evolved in Russia's varying historical contexts. Particular attention is paid to comparisons of racialization and racial injustice in America and in Russia. From classic Russian literature, to Soviet propaganda, to contemporary geopolitics, the course asks: How has "blackness" been historically understood and/or used by Russians, and what cultural and political legacies has that left in Russia's post- imperial and post-Soviet space?
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Russian Literature in Translation I: Pushkin to Dostoevsky
description: Survey of Russia's literary masterpieces of the early and mid-19th century, including Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, and Dostoevsky. From Pushkin's celebrated poem "The Bronze Horseman" and his novel in verse 'Eugene Onegin' to Gogol's grotesque and fantastic Peterburg tales and Dostoevsky's 'Crime and Punishment,' we will discuss questions of national identity and Empire, individual vs. the state, as well as other moral, political and philosophical issues that shaped Russian classical texts. Lectures and discussion. No knowledge of Russian is required.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Russian Novel
description: When one considers the impact of Russian literature on world literature, one thinks first of all of the novel. And indeed, since the late nineteenth century its readers all over the world could not resist its artistic powers. The course explores selected Russian novels form the nineteenth- to the twenty-first century. Our in-depth (slow) reading and discussions will be guided by the questions concerning the stylistic peculiarities of the novel, and its development in changing historical and cultural contexts. The course includes: Gogol's Dead Souls, Goncharov's Oblomov, Dostoevsky's Idiot, Bely's Petersburg, Platonov's The Fountain Pit, among others.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Totalitarian Art and Its Opponents
description: What does it mean for art to be political? Who or what decides what is art and what is non-art? To what extent do governments and the policies they make dictate and control artistic production? Can artists, writers and filmmakers also shape politics and ideology in their turn? Drawing on art history, literature, film studies and political theory, this course will investigate the complex inter-relationships between politics, ideology and aesthetics. More specifically, we will consider topics that examine issues of originality versus kitsch, avant-garde versus mass culture, abstraction versus figuration, state-sanctioned art and political propaganda versus art as a medium for political activism and resistance. Students will gain an appreciation of a wide range of different media, including architecture, painting, sculpture, printmaking, photography, film, music and literature.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Russian and Soviet Avant-Garde
description: Covering a period of intense artistic innovation from the early 1900s to the mid-1930s, this course traces the arc of the pioneering Russian and early Soviet avant-garde from its flowering in the mid nineteen teens to its eventual demise with the institutionalization of Socialist Realism as the sole sanctioned style of art. In the course of the semester, we will examine a diverse range of literary works, paintings, drawings, sculpture, prints, book, graphic and theater design, film, photography, and architecture by leading figures such as Vasily Kandinsky, Mikhail Larionov, Natalia Goncharova, El Lissitzky, Kazimir Malevich, Vladimir Tatlin, Liubov Popova, Alexandr Rodchenko, Olga Rozanova, Aleksei Kruchenykh, Velimir Khlebnikov, Vladimir Mayakovsky, Isaac Babel, Sergei Eisenstein, and Dziga Vertov, among others. We will also study several collaborative stage productions such as The Yellow Sound, Victory Over the Sun, and Zangezi.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Media Cultures of the Russian 1990s
description: Today's global media—marked by political "virtuality," disinformation, and conspiracy theories—found early expression in the media landscape of the Russian 1990s. Post-Soviet Russian society emerged alongside an explosion of new media, including a newly liberated press and television and the fledgling Internet. In this course, we will examine Russophone print, audiovisual, and early digital media, along with select performance and material culture artifacts dating to the "long 1990s"—from the mid-1980s to Putin's rise to power. In tracing these developments, we will see how even the boldest media experiments of the Russian 1990s continue to shape global culture and politics today. Weekly reading assignments for the class will be primarily taken from the digital humanities project, The Post-Soviet Public Sphere: A Multimedia Sourcebook of the Russian 1990s. All readings in English, with Russian originals also available for interested students.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Russian Romanticism
description: This course will examine the works of Zhukovsky, Batiushkov, Pushkin, Lermontov, Tiutchev, Bestuzhev-Marlinsky, Odoevsky, and Gogol in the context of Romanticist literary culture. Students will also read works by other European authors associated with Romanticism to elucidate the extent of the adherence of Russian writers to Romanticist aesthetics and philosophy. Advanced reading knowledge of Russian is required for this course.
registration_restrictions: Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: Elementary Sanskrit II
description: This course continues the survey of grammar and the reading exercises of SANS 100. The second half of this course reads selected passages of the Bhagavad Gītā and the beginning of the classic story of Nala and Damayantī from the Mahābhārata. Prerequisite: SANS 0100.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisite: SANS 0100.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: The Bhāgavata Purāṇa: Text and Reception
description: The Bhāgavata Purāṇa narrates the stories of Kṛṣṇa and other gods and is rich with philosophical and theological discourse. Though relatively late, it became one of the most prominent religious texts, attracting many formal commentaries from the 13th century into the modern period. In this course, students will apply their knowledge of the foundational grammar of language to interpret the complex, poetic language of the Bhāgavata, and learn the language and idioms of scholastic Sanskrit to access the interpretations of centuries of the Purāṇa's audiences.
registration_restrictions: Prerequisites: SANS 0300 or minimum score of WAIVE in 'Graduate Student PreReq'.Students in the Remote Study / Study Abroad cohort may not enroll.

title: American Sign Language I, II
description:
An immersive approach using authentic communication inside and outside of the classroom will be used to develop introductory communicative skills in American Sign Language. Authentic materials from diverse sources will provide an overview of the American Deaf community. Basic media literacy skills will be taught.
This is the first half of a year-long course whose first semester grade is normally a temporary one. Neither semester may be elected independently without special written permission. The final grade at the end of the course work in SIGN 0200 covers the entire year and is recorded as the final grade for both semesters.
